Danny Whaley,       
Respondent,

  Judge

Ronald K. Wray, II, Daniel B. White, Andrea M. Hawkins, all

C. Arthur Rutter, III, of Rutter Mills, of Norfolk; John E.

Marvin D. Infinger and Lydia Blessing Applegate, both of Haynsworth

  all of Shook Hardy & Bacon, of Washington, D.C., for Amici Curiae The American 
  Tort Reform Association and The South Carolina Chamber of Commerce.
Wendy J. Keefer, of Barnwell Whaley Patterson & Helms, 
  of Charleston; Robert W. Buffington of Haynsworth Sinkler Boyd, of Columbia, 
  for Amici Curiae Concerned Citizens for Responsible Government in Hampton County 
  and South Carolina Defense Trial Attorneys Association.
Stephen G. Morrison and Jacob A. Sommer, both of Nelson

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Danny 
  Whaley (Whaley), a locomotive engineer, filed a complaint against his former 
  employer, CSX Transportation, Inc. (CSX), alleging that, due to CSXâ€™s negligence, 
  he was injured as a result of exposure to excessive heat in a locomotive cab.Â  
  The jury awarded Whaley actual damages in the amount of $1,000,000.Â  CSX appealed, 
  and after certifying this case for review pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, we 
  affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
Factual/Procedural 
  Background
On May 24, 2000, Whaley reported 
  to work at CSXâ€™s Maxwell Yard in Greenwood, South Carolina, to operate a familiar 
  route from Greenwood to Laurens and then back. 
  [1] Â  On the way to Laurens, Whaley became disoriented and began experiencing 
  stomach cramps, nausea, and diarrhea.Â  He also noticed that he was not sweating, 
  even though it was very hot in the locomotive cab.Â  When he arrived in Laurens, 
  Whaley went inside the depot office to cool off in the air conditioning.Â  He 
  tried drinking water but stopped because it made his stomach cramp. 
Before Whaley began the return 
  trip to Greenwood, he realized that because of his symptoms, he would not be 
  able to make the trip.Â  He returned to the depot and called 911. 
EMS arrived, and after 
  learning that Whaley had not been drinking fluids and was experiencing dizziness, 
  the paramedic administered fluids through an IV.Â  The paramedic then recommended 
  that Whaley be taken to the emergency room â€œto be checked out.â€Â  Upon arrival 
  at the emergency room, Whaleyâ€™s temperature was either 99.1 or 99.7 degrees. 
  [2] Â  The emergency room physician determined that Whaley suffered heat 
  exhaustion, dehydration, and acute abdominal pain.Â  Whaley was kept in the emergency 
  room for approximately two hours for observation and then was released.Â Â  
After that day, May 24, 2000, 
  Whaley remained out of work for two weeks.Â  On June 7, with his family doctorâ€™s 
  permission, Whaley returned to work.Â  Whaley testified that he still felt bad 
  at the time, but he had to work or he would not get paid.
He worked June 7 and 8, and then 
  took the next three days off because he was still not feeling well.Â  The following 
  Monday, June 12, Whaley returned to work, but the very next day, June 13, would 
  be his last day working for CSX.Â  He testified that, even though he did not 
  feel well all day, he was able to complete his duties.
On June 14, 2000, Whaley went 
  to a previously scheduled appointment with his family doctor, Dr. Hatfield, 
  who told Whaley not to go back to work until doctors could determine why Whaley 
  felt so badly and why he was unable to sweat upon exertion.Â  Dr. Hatfield referred 
  Whaley to a number of specialists.Â  Dr. James, a cardiologist, testified that 
  he found no cardiac abnormalities and thought, instead, that Whaley had a viral 
  illness and, accordingly, referred him to an infectious disease specialist.Â  
  Dr. Holman, an internal medicine specialist, testified that Whaleyâ€™s symptoms 
  were consistent with a viral illness, heat exhaustion, or dehydration. 
  [3] Â  
After he was examined by the 
  specialists, Whaley testified that he concluded â€œ[t]here was nothing anybody 
  could do.â€Â  Because of his inability to perspire upon exertion, Whaley never 
  returned to work.Â  Since then, he has been limited in his physical activity, 
  but has still been able to enjoy hobbies such as fishing and hunting.Â  In January 
  2003, however, Whaley began experiencing dizziness and shortness of breath.Â  
  As a result, doctors installed a pacemaker. 
Whaley filed a complaint against 
  CSX in Hampton County on February 14, 2001, asserting claims under the Federal 
  Employerâ€™s Liability Act (FELA), 45 U.S.C. Â§ 51 et seq., and the Locomotive 
  Inspection Act (LIA), 49 U.S.C. Â§ 20701 et seq., and alleging, in sum, 
  that CSX was negligent for failing to provide him with a safe place to work.Â  
  On November 1, 2002, CSX filed a motion to transfer venue to Greenwood County, 
  which was denied.Â  The case proceeded to trial in Hampton County, and the jury 
  returned a verdict for Whaley in the amount of $1,000,000.Â  CSXâ€™s post-trial 
  motions were denied.
On appeal, CSX raises the following 
  issues for review:

  
    Did the trial court err in denying CSXâ€™s motion to transfer venue?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in denying CSXâ€™s motion for
    JNOV?
    
  
    Were Whaleyâ€™s claims preempted by federal law?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in allowing medical experts to testify on Whaleyâ€™s behalf 
  about causation?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in admitting evidence concerning injuries to other CSX 
  employees, other employee complaints, and equipment on other CSX locomotives?

Law/Analysis
I. Venue
A.Â  Residency
CSX argues that venue was improper 
  in Hampton County because CSX does not â€œresideâ€ in Hampton County.Â  We agree.
Venue is the place or geographical 
  location of trial.Â  Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 238, 442 S.E.2d 
  598, 600 (1994); see also In re Asbestosis Cases, 276 S.C. 579, 581, 
  281 S.E.2d 112, 115 (1981) (noting that â€œvenueâ€ refers to the county where the 
  action should be brought).Â  The venue statute in South Carolina provides, in 
  part, that an action â€œshall be tried in the county in which the defendant resides 
  at the time of the commencement of the action.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (1976).Â  
  A defendantâ€™s right to be tried in the county of its residence is a substantial 
  right.Â  Blizzard v. Miller, 306 S.C. 373, 375, 412 S.E.2d 406, 406 (1991).Â  

The question of where a defendant 
  resides is a question of law.Â  Breland v. Love Chevrolet Olds, Inc., 
  339 S.C. 89, 92, 529 S.E.2d 11, 13 (2000). When the facts concerning a defendantâ€™s 
  residence are uncontradicted, the trial court must, as a matter of law, change 
  venue to the county where the defendant resides.Â  Blizzard, 306 S.C. 
  at 375, 412 S.E.2d at 406-07.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Early decisions by this Court 
  established that, for purposes of venue, a foreign corporation resides in any 
  county where it has an office and agent for the transaction of business. Sanders 
  v. Allis Chalmers Mfg. Co., 235 S.C. 259, 111 S.E.2d 201 (1959); Hancock 
  v. S. Cotton Oil Co., 211 S.C. 432, 45 S.E.2d 850 (1947); Coker v. Sinclair 
  Refining Co., 203 S.C. 13, 25 S.E.2d 894 (1943); Shelton v. S. Kraft 
  Corp., 194 S.C. 81, 10 S.E.2d 341 (1940); Tucker v. Ingram, 187 S.C. 
  525, 198 S.E. 25 (1938); Campbell v. Mut. Benefit Health Corp. & Accident 
  Assâ€™n, 161 S.C. 49, 159 S.E. 490 (1931); see also Hayes v. Seaboard Air 
  Line Ry., 98 S.C. 6, 81 S.E. 1102 (1914) (holding that a foreign railroad 
  corporation resides in the county where it â€œowns a line of railwayâ€ and â€œmaintains 
  offices and agents . . . for the transaction of its businessâ€).Â  Domestic corporations, 
  on the other hand, have been held to reside (1) in any county where the corporation 
  maintains an agent and transacts its corporate business or (2) in the 
  county where the corporation maintains its principal place of business.Â  See 
  McGrath v. Piedmont Mut. Ins. Co., 74 S.C. 69, 72, 54 S.E. 218, 218-19 (1906); 
  Tobin v. Chester & L. Narrowgauge R.R. Co., 47 S.C. 387, 25 S.E. 
  283 (1896) (holding that a domestic railroad corporation resides in the county 
  â€œwhere its line is located, and where it maintains a public office for the transaction 
  of its business, and an agent upon whom process may be servedâ€).Â  
In 1941, however, this Court 
  expanded the definition of venue for domestic corporations.Â  In Miller 
  v. Boyle Constr. Co., this Court held that venue is proper in any county 
  where a domestic corporation â€œowns property and transacts business.â€Â  198 S.C. 
  166, 172, 17 S.E.2d 312, 314-15 (1941).Â  In support of its decision, the Court 
  relied upon language in a 1927 statute concerning service of process on and 
  jurisdiction over domestic corporations: 

in the case of domestic corporations[,] 
  service â€¦ shall be effective and confer jurisdiction over any domestic corporation 
  in any county where such domestic corporation shall own property and transact 
  business regardless of whether or not such domestic corporation maintains 
  an office or has agents in that county.Â  

Id. at 172, 17 S.E.2d at 
  315 (emphases added). Although the statute pertained to service and jurisdictionâ€”not 
  venueâ€”the Court decided that the statute â€œgoverned and controlledâ€ the question 
  of where a domestic corporation resides for purposes of venue.Â  Id.Â  
  As a result, counties where a domestic corporation owned property and transacted 
  business became an additional place where venue could be found proper.Â  
Six years later, the Court had 
  the opportunity to extend the â€œowns property and transacts businessâ€ test to 
  foreign corporations, but the Court declined to do so.Â  See Hancock 
  v. Southern Cotton Oil Co., 211 S.C. 432, 437, 45 S.E.2d 850, 853 (1947) 
  (holding that foreign corporations reside in any county where they maintain 
  an agent and office for the transaction of business).Â  In Hancock, the 
  Court squarely considered whether the rule established in Millerâ€”that 
  domestic corporations reside in any county where they own property and 
  transact businessâ€”applied to foreign corporations, and the Court held 
  that it did not.Â  The Court declined to extend the rule to foreign corporations 
  because the 1927 service statute, which formed the basis of the Courtâ€™s decision 
  in Miller, dealt only with domestic corporations, not foreign corporations.Â  
  If the legislature had intended for the statute to apply to foreign corporations, 
  the Court reasoned, then the statute would have been written accordingly.Â  The 
  Court was unwilling, therefore, to use the statute to define venue as proper 
  in any county where a foreign corporation owned property and transacted business.Â  
  Consequently, the Court maintained the long-standing rule that a foreign corporation 
  resides in any county where the corporation maintains an agent and office for 
  the transaction of business.Â  Id. at 438, 45 S.E.2d at 854.
Eventually, in 1964, the statute 
  concerning service and jurisdiction was amended to include foreign corporations.Â  
  The amended statute provided, in part, the following:Â  

in the case of domestic or 
  foreign corporations, service as effected under the terms of this section 
  shall be effective and confer jurisdiction over any domestic or foreign corporation 
  in any county where such domestic or foreign corporation shall own property 
  and transact business, regardless of whether or not such domestic or foreign 
  corporation maintains an office or has agents in that county.Â Â Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 10-421 (Supp. 
  1975) [4]  (emphases added).Â  
  Now that the service statute included both domestic and foreign corporations, 
  the question then became whether the Court would use the statute to expand the 
  definition of venue for foreign corporations, to include any county where a 
  foreign corporation owned property and transacted business. 
Soon after the service statute 
  was amended, the Court answered this question, holding that venue was proper 
  in a county where a foreign corporation owned property and transacted 
  business. Lott v. Claussens, Inc., 251 S.C. 478, 480, 163 S.E.2d 615, 
  616-17 (1968).Â  The Court reached this decision by relying exclusively on the 
  1964 service statute, without a single citation to the venue statute or precedent. 

Finally, in 1980, this Court 
  definitively established that, for a corporate defendant, venue is proper in 
  any county where such corporate defendantâ€”foreign or domesticâ€”owns property 
  and transacts business, regardless of whether the corporation maintains an office 
  and agent in that county.Â  In re Asbestosis Cases, 274 S.C. 421, 433, 
  266 S.E.2d 773, 778 (1980).Â  In that case, the Court began its analysis with 
  the proposition that venue for corporations may be predicated on either 
  the venue statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (1976), or the service of 
  process statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-210 (1976).Â  Because the Court reasoned 
  that both statutes addressed the venue issue, the Court read the two statutes 
  together. 
The venue statute, S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 15-7-30, entitled â€œActions which must be tried in county where defendant 
  resides,â€ provided, in part, the following:

[an] action shall be tried in 
  the county in which the defendant resides at the time of the commencement of 
  the action.Â  If there be more than one defendant then the action may be tried 
  in any county in which one or more of the defendants to such actions resides 
  at the time of the commencement of the action.Â  If none of the parties shall 
  reside in the State the action may be tried in any county which the plaintiff 
  shall designate in his complaint.Â  This section is subject however to the power 
  of the court to change the place of trial in certain cases as provided by law.

The service of process statute, 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-210, entitled, â€œService on corporations generally,â€ provided, 
  in part, the following: 

service as effected under the 
  terms of this section shall be effective and confer jurisdiction over 
  any domestic or foreign corporation in any county where such domestic or foreign 
  corporation shall own property and transact business, regardless of whether 
  or not such domestic or foreign corporation maintains an office or has agents 
  in that county.

(Emphases added).
Because the venue statute did 
  not define the term â€œresides,â€ the Court, as it had done in prior decisions, 
  looked to the service statute for guidance.Â  The Court explained its analysis 
  in the following way:Â  

[b]oth 15-7-30 and 15-9-210 obviously 
  deal with the same general subject matter. 
  [5] Â  With [this] principle in mind, it is logical to interpret â€œresidesâ€ 
  as used in section 15-7-30 to include, for the purpose of determining proper 
  venue, those counties in which any corporate defendant â€œshall own property and 
  transact businessâ€ as provided in section 15-9-210.

In re Asbestosis Cases, 
  274 S.C. at 426, 266 S.E.2d at 775.Â  Accordingly, without relying on precedent, 
  the Court held that because the defendant corporation did not own property or 
  transact business in Barnwell County, venue was not proper in that county, and 
  the case was remanded for transfer to Greenville County, where the defendant 
  had its only place of business. Â Id. at 433, 266 S.E.2d at 778.
A year later, the Court 
  delineated the three locations where a corporationâ€™s residence may be established 
  for purposes of venue:

(1) county where a domestic corporation 
  has its principal place of business, Lucas v. Atlantic Greyhound Federal 
  Credit Union . ..; or
(2) county where a domestic or 
  foreign corporation maintains an office and agent for the transaction of business, 
  Lucas v. Atlantic Greyhound Federal Credit Union . . .; Shelton v. 
  Southern Kraft Corp., 195 S.C. 81, 10 S.E.2d 341 (1940); or
(3) county where a domestic or 
  foreign corporation owns property or transacts business (Â§ 15-9-210), Code of 
  Laws of South Carolina (1976). 

In re Asbestosis Cases, 
  276 S.C. 579, 582, 281 S.E.2d 112, 114 (1981).Â  Notably, the Court cited case 
  law in support of the â€œoffice and agentâ€ test and statutory law in support of 
  the â€œowns property and transacts businessâ€ test.Â  Id.
Soon after the Court 
  published the In re Asbestosis Cases decisions, the legislature rewrote 
  section 15-9-210, the service statute.Â  The revised service statute no longer 
  included the phrase â€œown property and transact businessâ€ and no longer referred 
  to jurisdiction.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-210 (Supp. 1981).Â  Moreover, 
  the revised service statute dealt only with domestic corporations; provisions 
  regarding service on foreign corporations were moved to another section of the 
  Code.Â  See Â§ 15-9-240 (Supp. 1981).Â  As a result of these significant 
  revisions, there is no longer a statutory basis for laying venue in a county 
  where a corporation â€œowns property and transacts business.â€Â  
Although the statutory basis 
  for the â€œowns property and transacts businessâ€ test no longer exists, South 
  Carolina appellate courts have continued to cite the test.Â  See Dove v. Gold 
  Kist, Inc., 314 S.C at 239, 442 S.E.2d at 600-01; McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley 
  & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 335, 479 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Only one 
  case, however, has actually applied the test to reach its holding.Â  See Thomas 
  & Howard Co., Inc. v. Wetterau, Inc., 291 S.C. 237, 239, 353 S.E.2d 
  141, 142 (1987) (holding that a corporation resides in county where it owns 
  property and transacts business).
In the present case, the trial 
  court [6]  relied upon this Courtâ€™s decisions in Thomas 
  & Howard and the two In re Asbestosis Cases to support his decision 
  to deny CSXâ€™s motion to change venue, finding that CSX was a resident of Hampton 
  County because it owned property and transacted business in Hampton County.Â  
  In so ruling, the trial court also relied, in part, on dicta from this Courtâ€™s 
  most recent case concerning venue, Breland v. Love Chevrolet, 339 S.C. 
  at 94, 529 S.E.2d at 13.Â  In Breland, this Court held that a denial of 
  a motion to change venue was not immediately appealable.Â  Id. at 96, 
  529 S.E.2d at 14.Â  In dicta, however, the Court stated, â€œit is clear that [the 
  defendantâ€™s] substantial and continuous contacts with Hampton County 
  will sustain the trials courtâ€™s decision [to deny the motion to change venue].â€Â  
  Id. at 94, 529 S.E.2d at 13 (emphasis added).Â  Relying on this language, 
  the trial court in the present case found that the Supreme Court â€œclearly indicated 
  that the foreign corporationâ€™s substantial and continuous contacts with 
  a particular county support[ed] venue.â€ (Emphasis added).Â  
We hold that the trial court 
  erred in finding that CSX resides in Hampton County.Â  First, we find that the 
  trial court improperly relied upon dicta in Breland.Â  As the trial judge 
  in the present case acknowledged, the merits of the defendantâ€™s motion to change 
  venue was not before this Court.Â  Moreover, we did not hold that â€œsubstantial 
  and continuous contactsâ€ in a particular county satisfies the â€œowns property 
  and transacts businessâ€ test.Â  Therefore, the dicta in Breland does not 
  support the trial courtâ€™s ruling. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Second, we hold that the â€œowns 
  property and transacts businessâ€ test is no longer a viable test for determining 
  whether venue is proper.Â  To begin, the test was improperly created by the Court 
  reading two statutes, in tandem, that addressed separate and distinct concepts.Â  
  See In re Asbestosis Cases, 274 S.C. at 426, 266 S.E.2d at 775.Â  Section 
  15-9-210 addressed service of process and jurisdiction, while section 15-7-30 
  addressedâ€”and still does todayâ€”venue.Â  Venue is the place or geographical location 
  of trial.Â  Dove, 314 S.C. at 238, 442 S.E.2dÂ  at 600; see also In 
  re Asbestosis Cases, 276 S.C. at 581, 281 S.E.2d at 114.Â  Jurisdiction, 
  on the other hand, is the power of a court to decide a case.Â  Blackâ€™s Law 
  Dictionary 855 (7th ed. 1999); see also Dove, 314 S.C. at 237-38, 
  442 S.E.2d at 600 (defining subject matter jurisdiction as the courtâ€™s power 
  to hear and determine a particular class of cases).Â  Proper service of process 
  on a defendant, therefore, confers personal jurisdiction over the defendant.Â  
  Moore v. Simpson, 322 S.C. 518, 523, 473 S.E.2d 64, 66 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
  Consequently, a court may have personal jurisdiction over a properly served 
  defendant by effecting personal service in a particular geographical location 
  without venue being proper in the place of service.Â  Therefore, because these 
  statutes do not address the same concepts, the Court improperly used the language 
  from the service statute to define the term â€œresidesâ€ in the venue statute.
Even if we were to find that 
  the Court properly used the â€œowns property and transacts businessâ€ language 
  from the service statute to define â€œresides,â€ we no longer support a test that, 
  derived from statute, no longer exists in that statute.Â  Again, when rewriting 
  section 15-9-210, the legislature removed the â€œowns property and transacts businessâ€ 
  language.Â  As a result, this Court can no longer point to a statute, as it did 
  in prior decisions, including the two In re Asbestosis Cases decisions 
  and the earlier decision in Lott v. Claussens, Inc., to find venue proper 
  in a county where a corporate defendant owns property and transacts business.Â  
  Therefore, in our decision today, we are unwilling to uphold the â€œowns property 
  and transacts businessâ€ test.Â Â Â  
Finally, as recently as 1994, 
  this Court has continued to recognize that venue is proper where a corporate 
  defendant maintains an office and agent for the transaction of business.Â  Dove, 
  314 S.C. at 238, 442 S.E.2d at 600; Stewart v. Nichols, 282 S.C. 402, 
  404, 318 S.E.2d 369, 370 (1984).Â  In Dove, we were unwilling to find 
  that venue was proper in Richland County on the sole basis that the defendant 
  corporation maintained a retail outlet in the county. Dove, 314 S.C. 
  at 239, 442 S.E.2d at 601.Â  Instead, the Court was concerned with whether the 
  defendant maintained an agent in Richland County, and, therefore, remanded 
  the case to the trial court to make such a determination.Â  Id.Â  
Accordingly, we hold that for 
  purposes of venue, a defendant corporation resides in any county where it (1) 
  maintains its principal place of business or (2) maintains an office and agent 
  for the transaction of business.Â  
CSX is incorporated under Virginia 
  law, and its principal place of business is in Florida.Â  Although CSX owns property 
  and transacts business in Hampton County, it does not maintain an office and 
  agent for the transaction of business there.Â  Therefore, the trial court erred 
  in finding that venue was proper in Hampton County. 
B.Â  Convenience 
  and Justice
CSX argues that even if it did 
  reside in Hampton County, its motion to change venue should have been granted 
  based on the convenience of witnesses and the ends of justice.  
  [7] Â  We agree.
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Discretionary 
  authority
A trial judge may change the 
  place of trial â€œ[w]hen the convenience of witnesses and the ends of justice 
  would be promoted by the change.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-100(3) (1976).Â  Unlike 
  the determination of residency, which is a question of law, it is within the 
  trial judgeâ€™s discretion to determine whether to grant a motion to change venue 
  based on the convenience of the witnesses and the ends of justice.Â  Varnadoe 
  v. Hicks, 264 S.C. 216, 219, 213 S.E.2d 736, 737 (1975).
Â 
In the present case, the trial 
  judge found that he lacked the discretionary authority to transfer the case 
  based on subsection 2 of South Carolinaâ€™s long-arm statute. 
  [8] Â  Subsection 2 provides that when jurisdiction is based solely on the 
  long-arm statute, a trial judge is not permitted to transfer venue for the convenience 
  of witnesses and the ends of justice. 
  [9] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803(2) (1976).Â  Because the trial judge found 
  that personal jurisdiction in this case was based solely on the long-arm statute, 
  he found that he was without authority to transfer the case.Â  We disagree.
The trial courtâ€™s jurisdiction 
  was not based solely on the long-arm statuteâ€™s bare threshold level of minimum 
  contacts.Â  Another statutory basis for jurisdiction existed under S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 36-2-802 (1976), which provides that â€œ[a] court may exercise personal 
  jurisdiction over a person domiciled in, organized under the laws of, doing 
  business, or maintaining his or her principal place of business in, this 
  State as to any cause of action.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  Evidence in the record 
  demonstrates that CSX conducts business in this state, owns property in this 
  state, and has an agent for service of process in this state. 
  [10] Â  
Because we find that CSX was 
  â€œdoing businessâ€ in this state, we hold that the trial court erred in ruling 
  that jurisdiction was based solely on the long-arm statute.Â  Consequently, the 
  trial judge erred in ruling that he did not have the discretionary authority 
  to transfer the case based on the convenience of the witnesses and the ends 
  of justice.
  2.                
Merits 
   
Even though the trial judge found 
  that he did not have the authority to transfer the case based on convenience 
  of the witnesses and the ends of justice, the judge addressed the merits of 
  the motion, found that CSX did not make a prima facie showing that the 
  witnesses would be inconvenienced by a trial in Hampton County, and, accordingly, 
  ruled that CSXâ€™s motion, if considered on the merits, would be denied.Â Â  
Either party may make a motion 
  to change venue based on convenience of the witnesses and the ends of justice.Â  
  McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 334, 479 S.E.2d 67, 
  70 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The moving party has the burden of making a prima facie 
  showing that both the convenience of the witnesses and the ends of justice would 
  be promoted.Â  Mixson v. Agricultural Helicopters, Inc., 260 S.C. 532, 
  197 S.E.2d 663 (1973).Â  The showing must be based on â€œcompetent evidence,â€ not 
  mere â€œbeliefs, opinions, and conclusions of the witnesses.â€Â  Id.Â  Once 
  such a showing has been made, the burden shifts to the party opposing the motion 
  to overcome at least one of the two requirements.Â  Id.
At the motion hearing, CSX presented 
  evidence showing that almost every witness identified by each of the parties 
  lived either in Greenwood County or the contiguous counties of Laurens and Abbeville. [11] Â  With the exception of a medical expert retained 
  by Whaley to review his condition in preparation for trial, none of the witnesses 
  were residents of Hampton County. [12] Â  In addition, the alleged 
  injuries occurred either in Greenwood or Laurens Counties, not Hampton County.Â  
  Finally, CSX submitted deposition excerpts from two of Whaleyâ€™s treating physicians 
  who testified that it would be inconvenient for them to travel from Greenwood 
  to Hampton County for trial. [13] 
  
Based on this evidence, we find 
  that CSX made a prima facie showing that Hampton County was not a convenient 
  place for trial.Â  Moreover, we hold that the ends of justice were not promoted 
  by having this case tried in Hampton County.Â  See Varnadoe v. Hicks, 
  264 S.C. 216, 213 S.E.2d 736 (1975) (convenience of the witnesses is a factor 
  the court may consider in deciding whether a change of venue would promote the 
  ends of justice); Holden v. Beach, 228 S.C. 234, 89 S.E.2d 433 (1955) 
  (the ends of justice are promoted by having a jury from the same area as the 
  witnesses evaluate witness credibility).
Therefore, we hold that the trial 
  judge erred in ruling that CSX failed to make a prima facie showing that 
  the convenience of witnesses and the ends of justice would be promoted by a 
  change of venue.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  JNOV
CSX argues that Whaley did not 
  present a sufficient amount of evidence from which a reasonable and fair-minded 
  juror could have found that CSX violated the Federal Employerâ€™s Liability Act 
  (FELA) or the Locomotive Inspection Act (LIA).Â  Accordingly, CSX argues, the 
  trial court erred in denying CSXâ€™s motion for JNOV on these two claims.Â  We 
  agree that the trial court erred in denying the motion on the LIA claim, but 
  we disagree that the court erred in denying the motion on the FELA claim. 
A.Â  FELA claim
When deciding whether to grant 
  a motion for JNOV in a FELA action, a state court must apply the federal standard.Â  
  Rogers v. Norfolk S. Corp., 356 S.C. 85, 91, 588 S.E.2d 87, 90 (2003).Â  
  The federal standard for sufficiency of evidence, which applies to both trial 
  and appellate courts, is the following:Â  

the evidence and all reasonable 
  inferences from it are assessed in the light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party . . . and the credibility of all evidence favoring the non-moving party 
  is assumed. . . .Â  Assessed in this way, the evidence must then be â€œof such 
  quality and weight that reasonable and fair-minded men in the exercise of impartial 
  judgment could reasonably return a verdict for the non-moving party. . . .â€Â  
  A â€œmere scintilla of evidenceâ€ is not sufficient to withstand the challenge.Â  


Id. at 91-92, 588 S.E.2d 
  at 90 (internal citations omitted).Â  Therefore, the non-moving party must present 
  â€œmore than a scintilla of evidence to establish his claim.â€Â  Id. at 92, 
  588 S.E.2d at 90. 
Under FELA, railroad carriers 
  are liable to their employees for injury resulting, in whole or in part, from 
  the employerâ€™s negligence.Â  45 U.S.C. Â§ 51 (2000).Â  Moreover, a railroad has 
  a non-delegable duty to provide its employees with a safe place to work. [14] Â  Rogers, 356 S.C. at 92, 588 S.E.2d at 90 (citations 
  omitted).Â  This duty, however, extends only to foreseeable dangers.Â  Id.Â  
  To recover, a plaintiff must prove the common law elements of negligence: 
  duty, breach, causation, and damages. Id. at 91, 588 S.E.2d at 90.Â  
Viewing the evidence and its 
  inferences in the light most favorable to Whaley, we find that Whaley presented 
  more than a scintilla of evidence to support a verdict in his favor on the FELA 
  claim.Â  At trial, Whaley presented the testimony of Tony Smith, general chairman 
  for the Eastern Lines General Committee of Adjustment on CSX, who admitted that 
  locomotive cabs become very hot during the summer months.Â  In addition, Larry 
  Koster, chief mechanical officer for CSX, testified that CSX was aware that 
  extreme heat and airflow were issues in locomotives. Â Finally, Gregory Martin, 
  chief mechanical officer for engineering and quality assurance for CSX, testified 
  that CSX had studied the issue of excessive heat in locomotive cabs. 
Based on this testimony, we find 
  that Whaley presented more than a scintilla of evidence to establish that CSX 
  knew or, in the exercise of ordinary care, should have known that the conditions 
  inside its locomotives could constitute an unsafe work environment.Â  Therefore, 
  we hold that Whaley presented enough evidence from which a fair-minded juror 
  could differ on whether CSX was negligent and whether that negligence contributed 
  to Whaleyâ€™s injury.Â  
B.Â  LIA claim
We find, however, that the trial 
  court erred in denying the JNOV motion on the LIA claim.Â  Under the LIA, railroad 
  carriers must ensure that their locomotives and all parts and appurtenances 
  â€œare in proper condition and safe to operate without unnecessary danger of personal 
  injury.â€Â  49 U.S.C. Â§ 20701 (2000).Â  In addition, LIA regulations require that 
  locomotives â€œbe provided with proper ventilation.â€Â  49 C.F.R. 229.119(d) (2003).Â  
  But â€œa carrier cannot be held liable under the [LIA] for failure to install 
  equipment on a locomotive unless the omitted equipment (1) is required by applicable 
  federal regulations; or (2) constitutes an integral or essential part of a completed 
  locomotive.â€Â  Mosco v. Baltimore & Ohio R.R., 817 F.2d 1088, 1091 
  (4th Cir. 1987).
In this case, Whaley argues that 
  the locomotives he operated lacked proper ventilation.Â  But he did not present 
  any evidence that the locomotives and their parts were not in proper condition.Â  
  Moreover, he did not present any evidence that CSX failed to install equipment 
  that was required under federal regulations or that constituted an integral 
  or essential part of the locomotive.Â  Because Whaley did not present even a 
  scintilla of evidence to establish a claim under the LIA, we hold that a fair, 
  impartial, and reasonable juror could not have returned a verdict in Whaleyâ€™s 
  favor on the LIA claim.Â  
Consequently, we hold that the 
  trial court erred in denying CSXâ€™s motion for JNOV on the LIA claim but properly 
  denied the motion on the FELA claim.Â Â Â  
III. 
Preemption
CSX argues that the FELA and 
  LIA claims are precluded and preempted under federal law. [15] Â  We agree that the LIA claim 
  is preempted but hold that the FELA claim is not.
The United States Supreme Court 
  has held that the LIAâ€™s predecessor, the Boiler Inspection Act, was intended 
  to â€œoccupy the fieldâ€ of locomotive regulation.Â  Napier v. Atl. Coast Line 
  R. Co., 272 U.S. 605, 613 (1924).Â  As a result, any state regulation of 
  locomotives, e.g., to promote health and comfort or safety, is precluded and 
  preempted by federal law.Â  Id. at 612-13; see also General Motors 
  Corp. v. Kilgore, 853 So.2d 171 (Ala. 2002) (holding that the LIA preempts 
  state common law claims brought in wrongful death action).Â Â  
In the present case, we hold 
  that Whaleyâ€™s claim under the LIA is preempted by federal law.Â  Federal law 
  does not require that CSX install fans or air conditioners in its locomotives.Â  
  To uphold the juryâ€™s verdict would support a finding of liability despite CSXâ€™s 
  compliance with all applicable statutes and regulations and would force CSX 
  to alter its locomotives in a way that would conflict with the uniformity and 
  consistency that the LIA is designed to provide.Â  As a result, CSX would be 
  forced to install cooling devices on all locomotives to protect itself against 
  future lawsuits in South Carolina.Â  Therefore, we hold that Whaleyâ€™s claim under 
  the LIA is preempted.Â  
But Whaleyâ€™s negligence claimâ€”that 
  his employer did not provide a safe place to workâ€”is not preempted by federal 
  law.Â  A claim under FELA gives rise to an ordinary negligence action, which 
  is governed by state law.Â  Therefore, to the extent Whaley had a viable claim, 
  he could have brought it under the FELA only.Â  
  IV.          
Expert 
  Testimony  
CSX argues that the trial court 
  erred in allowing Whaley to present expert testimony that heat exposure caused 
  Whaleyâ€™s current inability to sweat.Â  Moreover, CSX argues that the evidence 
  did not meet the standard for admissibility, was unreliable, lacked proper foundation, 
  and was based on facts not in evidence.
After reviewing the record, we 
  find that this issue is not preserved for review.Â  See Holy Loch Distributors, 
  Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000) (to preserve 
  an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled 
  upon by the trial court).Â  
CSX argues that the trial court 
  erred in allowing Drs. Shealy, Waheed, and Collins to testify as to causation.Â  
  But there is no evidence in the record that CSX objected, at all, to the testimony 
  of Drs. Shealy and Waheed during trial.Â  CSX did, however, object to Dr. Collinsâ€™s 
  testimony, on the basis that it did not meet the standard of reliability.Â  But 
  this objection was apparently raised and ruled upon in a side bar, and the contents 
  of the side bar are not part of the record. 
  [16] Â  Moreover, when counsel attempted to put the contents of the side 
  bar on the record, the trial judge interrupted to explain that the objection 
  had been overruled in the side bar, not because the judge thought the testimony 
  met the standard of reliability, but because counsel failed to lay a foundation 
  for the objection.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not rule upon the issue now 
  raised by CSX in this appeal.Â  For these reasons, we find that this issue is 
  not preserved for review. Â Â 
  V.              
Other Evidence 
   
CSX argues that the trial court 
  erred in admitting evidence of other employee complaints about the temperature 
  in locomotives.Â  CSX also argues that the trial court erred in admitting evidence 
  about fans, air conditioners, and white-painted roofs on other locomotives. 
  We agree.Â  
Evidence of similar accidents, 
  transactions, or happenings is admissible in South Carolina where there is some 
  special relation between them tending to prove or disprove some fact in dispute.Â  
  Brewer v. Morris, 269 S.C. 607, 610, 239 S.E.2d 318, 319 (1977).Â  This 
  rule, which governs the admissibility of prior accidents, transactions, or happenings, 
  is based on â€œrelevancy, logic, and common sense.â€Â  Id.Â Â  Because evidence 
  of other accidents may be highly prejudicial, â€œ[a] plaintiff must present a 
  factual foundation for the court to determine that the other accidents were 
  â€˜substantially similarâ€™ to the accident at issue.â€Â  Buckman v. Bombardier 
  Corp., 893 F. Supp. 547, 552 (E.D.N.C. 1995).
Relevant evidence is â€œevidence 
  having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence 
  to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would 
  be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may 
  be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger 
  of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by 
  considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative 
  evidence.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The admission of evidence is within the trial judgeâ€™s 
  discretion and his decision will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002).
In the present case, the trial 
  judge permitted Whaley to submit evidence that, between 1984 and 2000, CSX had 
  received ninety-seven employee complaints about heat.Â  In addition, the trial 
  judge permitted Whaley to introduce evidence that, between 1993 and 2000, eighteen 
  CSX employees had suffered heat stroke.Â  Finally, the judge allowed Whaley to 
  introduce letters written to CSX by union officials complaining about heat.Â  

We hold that this evidence should 
  not have been admitted.Â  Whaley did not establish that the reported complaints 
  and injuries stemmed from the same or similar circumstances as his injuries.Â  
  Because Whaley did not establish that the other employees were injured under 
  similar circumstances, much less under substantially similar circumstances, 
  the trial judge erred in admitting the evidence.
The trial judge also allowed 
  Whaley to introduce evidence that some CSX locomotive cabs are equipped with 
  fans or air conditioners, and that the tops of some cabs are painted white.Â  
  We find that this evidence was not relevant to Whaleyâ€™s claim that the locomotives 
  in which he was injured were unsafe to operate or were not properly ventilated.Â  
  Moreover, based on our holding that the LIA claim is preempted, the evidence 
  should not have been admitted to show that CSX was liable for failing to install 
  particular cooling devices. 
Therefore, we hold that the trial 
  judge erred in allowing Whaley to introduce this evidence.Â  
Conclusion
In sum, we reverse the 
  trial courtâ€™s ruling denying CSXâ€™s motion to change venue.Â  CSX does not reside 
  in Hampton County for purposes of venue, and therefore the case should not have 
  been tried in Hampton County.Â  Moreover, the case should have been transferred 
  to Greenwood County on the basis of the convenience of witnesses and the ends 
  of justice.Â  
 In addition, we reverse 
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling denying CSXâ€™s motion for JNOV on the LIA claim.Â  But 
  we affirm the trial court ruling denying CSXâ€™s motion for JNOV on the FELA claim.Â  
  As a result, Whaley may proceed with the FELA claim upon re-trial.Â  
Finally, we reverse 
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling admitting certain evidence regarding other employee 
  complaints and regarding fans, air conditioners, and white-painted roofs on 
  other locomotives.Â  
This case is therefore remanded 
  to Greenwood County to be tried in accordance with this opinion. [17] 
 MOORE, WALLER and 
  BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that the trial court erred 
  in denying CSXâ€™s motion for a change of venue pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 
  (1976).Â  Having found this statute controls, I would not reach the other venue 
  issues.Â  I therefore join Part I A of the majority, but decline to join Part 
  I B.
I also join the majorityâ€™s decision in Part II affirming the trial 
  courtâ€™s denial of CSXâ€™s JNOV motion as it related to the FELA claim and reversing 
  as to the LIA claim.Â  Therefore, I find it unnecessary to reach CSXâ€™s 
  curious preemption argument as to the LIA cause of action.Â  Moreover, 
  like the LIA claim, the FELA claim was brought pursuant to a federal 
  act, and does not require us to decide whether these statutes preempt a state 
  law claim.Â  I therefore decline to join Part III.Â  While I join the majorityâ€™s 
  disposition of the evidentiary issues in Parts IV and V, I do so with the understanding 
  that some of these evidentiary objections may be renewed at the next trial.
For the reasons given above, I concur in the majorityâ€™s decision 
  to remand the FELA claim for a new trial. 
  [18] Â Â  

 
   
    [1]  The route was thirty miles each way, and with time spent switching 
    cars and waiting, it took approximately twelve hours to complete a round trip.

 
   
    [2]  The temperature on the emergency room record appears as 99.1, but 
    the emergency room doctor testified that Whaley had a temperature of 99.7.

 
   
    [3]  Whaley also saw Dr. Rodillo, who administered a stress test.Â  The 
    results of this test are not part of the record.Â  In addition, Whaley mentioned 
    the name of a fourth specialist, Dr. Smith, whom he saw shortly after his 
    alleged injury, but the record does provide the details of this treatment.Â  
  

 
   
    [4]  This statute was subsequently codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-210 
    (1976).

 
   
    [5]  Throughout the opinion, the Court intertwined the concepts of service, 
    jurisdiction, and venue.Â  For example, the Court viewed the 1964 amendment 
    to the service statuteâ€”which provided that service on a domestic or 
    foreign corporation was proper and conferred jurisdiction in any county where 
    the corporation owned property and transacted businessâ€”as an amendment that 
    expanded the law of venue.Â  Id. at 426, 266 S.E.2d 775. 

 
   
    [6]  Pre-trial rulings in this case on the venue issue were made by Circuit 
    Court Judge J. Cordell Maddox, Jr.Â  The case was tried to a jury before Circuit 
    Court Judge Perry M. Buckner, who made the evidentiary rulings and post-verdict 
    rulings.Â  We have referred to these judges collectively as â€œthe trial courtâ€ 
    or â€œthe trial judge.â€Â  Judge Maddox and Judge Buckner are skilled and experienced 
    trial judges who did not have the benefit of our rulings here when they conscientiously 
    applied precedent as it then existed. 

 
   
    [7]  Although we hold that venue was improper in Hampton County because 
    CSX did not â€œresideâ€ there, we address the alternative basis upon which venue 
    was improperâ€”the convenience of witnesses and the ends of justiceâ€”because 
    we seek to issue a comprehensive decision that clarifies the law of venue.Â  
    Moreover, because the incidents and parties involved in the underlying lawsuit 
    had no rational connection to the county in which this case was tried, we 
    cannot ignore a trial court ruling that fails to base venue on principles 
    of convenience and justice, particularly when such rulings may undermine the 
    publicâ€™s confidence in our judicial system. 

 
   
    [8]  The long-arm statute confers personal jurisdiction over a nonresident 
    defendant for specific conduct occurring in this state.Â  S.C. Code Â§ 36-2-803(1) 
    (1976).Â Â  

 
    [9] We note that South 
    Carolina is the only state that prohibits nonresident defendantsâ€”defendants 
    who are brought into a South Carolina court solely on the basis of the long-arm 
    statuteâ€”from transferring venue for the convenience of witnesses and the ends 
    of justice.Â  See Timothy Clardy, Nonresident Defendants Donâ€™t Deserve 
    Convenience or Justice in South Carolina, 55 S.C. L. Rev. 443 (2004) (arguing 
    that section 2 of the long-arm statute violates the Equal Protection Clause 
    and the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Article IV, Section 2 of the United 
    States Constitution).Â  We do not, however, consider the constitutionality 
    of subsection 2 of the long-arm statute.

 
   
    [10]  In fact, in its amended answer to the complaint, CSX admitted that 
    it â€œdoes business in South Carolina.â€

 
   
     
    [11]    This evidence was presented in the form of answers to interrogatories.

 
   [12]  In fact, at trial, Whaley 
    presented the testimony of eleven witnesses by video deposition, instead of 
    by live testimony, in Hampton County.

 
   
    [13]  At oral argument before this Court, Whaleyâ€™s counsel was asked the 
    following question: â€œWhy was this suit brought in Hampton County?â€Â  Counsel 
    answered, â€œIt was brought there because weâ€™re the lawyers.â€Â  Later, counsel 
    modified his answer, stating that the suit was brought in Hampton County because 
    â€œweâ€™re the lawyer and they [CSX] are residents there.â€Â  In either case, the 
    location of a lawyerâ€™s office should not enter into the analysis of whether 
    a defendant resides in a particular county for purposes of venue.Â Â Â  

 
   
    [14]  We note that FELA does not impose a duty on railroads to provide 
    employees with air-conditioned locomotives. Norfolk Southern Ry. Co. v. 
    Denson, 774 So.2d 549, 556 (Ala. 2000).

 
   
    [15]  CSX raised this argument several times throughout the trial, and 
    the trial judge ruled that the argument failed as a matter of law.Â  Because 
    CSX will likely raise this preemption argument on remand, we address the merits 
    of this argument in the interest of judicial economy.Â  

 
   
    [16]  The record does contain the contents of a side bar in which CSX 
    objected to Dr. Collinsâ€™s testimony based on hearsay, not based on the grounds 
    raised in this appeal. 

 
   
    [17]  The concurrence makes the technical procedural point that the case 
    should be remanded to Hampton County, instead of Greenwood County, without 
    prejudice to CSXâ€™s right to renew its motion to change venue.Â  First, in remanding 
    this case, we direct the remittitur to be sent to the trial court in Hampton 
    County, where, by order of this Court, the case will be transferred to Greenwood 
    County.Â  Second, in light of todayâ€™s opinion, we do not think it is necessary 
    for CSX to renew its motion to change venue, as suggested in the concurring 
    opinion.Â Â Â  

 
   [18]  In my view, the case must be remanded to Hampton 
    County, without prejudice to CSXâ€™s right to renew its motion to change venue. 
    See State v. Hunter, 82 S.C. 152, 63 S.E. 685 (1909) (remittitur 
    returned to county where appeal from venue order originated).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Greenwood County Council,       
Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Emmett F.Â  Brooks, Former Interim Clerk of Court for Greenwood County, 
        and Ingram Moon, Interim Clerk of Court for Greenwood County,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No. 25936
Heard November 30, 2004 - Filed February 
  7, 2005


Charles M. Watson, Jr., of Watson Law Firm, of Greenwood, for Petitioner.
Jon Eric Newlon, of The McCravy & Newton Law Firm, P.A., of Greenwood, 
  for Respondents.


JUSTICE WALLER:Â Â  This case was filed in the original jurisdiction 
  of the Court seeking a declaratory judgmentÂ  determining whether the Greenwood 
  County Council (County) had the authority to reduce the salary ofÂ  an Interim 
  Clerk of Court.Â  We find the County did not have the authority to reduce the 
  salary of an Interim Clerk of Court.Â  
FACTS
In 1999, Louise Davis (Davis), with twenty-eight (28) years 
  experience in the Clerkâ€™s Office, was appointed the Interim Clerk of Court for 
  County.Â  Davis notified the County Manager that she expected the same pay as 
  her predecessor and the County complied.Â Â  In November 2000, Davis was elected 
  as Clerk of Court.Â  On June 30, 2003, Davis retired.Â  She was earning $46,592.00 
  at the time of her retirement.Â  On the same day, the County passed its budget 
  for the fiscal year 2003-2004 and reduced the salary for the Clerk of Court 
  position to $35,000.Â  
On August 6, 2003, Governor Mark Sanford appointed Emmett 
  Brooks (Brooks) as the Clerk of Court to serve the remainder of Davisâ€™ term 
  until January 1, 2005. [1]  Apparently, Governor Sanford, 
  unaware of the salary reduction in the Countyâ€™s budget, informed Brooks that 
  he would receive the same salary that Davis had received before she retired.Â  
  After accepting the appointment, Brooks was informed the salary would be only 
  $35,000.Â  
The County brought this action seeking a determination of 
  whether it had the authority to reduce the Clerk of Courtâ€™s salary.Â  Brooks 
  answered and counterclaimed. Â Brooks and the County subsequently settled and 
  as part of the agreement, Brooks resigned. In July 2004, the Governor appointed 
  the current Interim Clerk of Court, Ingram Moon (Moon), and the Court ordered 
  Moon added as a party to this action. 
  [2] Â  
ISSUE

Did the County have the authority to reduce the salary of 
  the Interim Clerks of Court? 

DISCUSSION
The County contends it was not prohibited from reducing 
  the salary of the Interim Clerks of Court.Â  Two code sections are applicable 
  to this issue. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-21-300 (Supp. 2003) provides, in pertinent 
  part: â€œThe clerks of court and registers of deeds of the several counties shall 
  receive such salaries for performance of their duties as may be fixed by the 
  governing body of the county, which shall not be diminished during their 
  terms of office . . . â€œ (emphasis added).Â  
Additionally, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-30(7) (Supp. 2003) provides 
  the county with the authority:Â  

to develop personnel system policies and procedures for 
  county employees by which all county employees are regulated except those 
  elected directly by the people, and to be responsible for the employment 
  and discharge of county personnel in those county departments in which the employment 
  authority is vested in the county government. This employment and discharge 
  authority does not extend to any personnel employed in departments or agencies 
  under the direction of an elected official or an official appointed by an 
  authority outside county government. . . .The salary of those officials 
  elected by the people may be increased but may not be reduced during the 
  terms for which they are electedÂ  . . .

(emphasis added).
Section 4-9-30(7) prohibits the reduction of a salary â€œduring the term for 
  which the official is electedâ€ and Â§ 8-21-300 prohibits a salary reduction during 
  an elected officialâ€™s â€œterm of office.â€ 
  [3] Â Â  
There are no South Carolina cases addressing whether the salary of an interim 
  official appointed to fill an unexpired term can be reduced.Â  However, there 
  have been several Attorney General Opinions which have concluded that the salary 
  may not be reduced during the unexpired term of the office.Â  1985 Op. Atty. 
  Gen., No. 85-107. [4] Â Â  Furthermore, several cases 
  from other jurisdictions have also addressed similar prohibitions and held that 
  the phrase â€œterms of officeâ€ means the unexpired term of the previously elected 
  official.Â  Lee v. Peach Cty. Bd. Of Commâ€™rs, 497 S.E.2d 562 (Ga. 1998); 
  McKesson v. Lowery, 335 P.2d 662 (Ca. 1959).Â  
One of the purposes behind legislation which prohibits salary changes during 
  an elected officialâ€™s term is to establish certainty as to the salary and to 
  prevent elected officials from using undue influence to secure salary increases.Â  
  McKesson, 335 P.2d at 663.Â  Further, increases should be enacted for 
  the benefit of the office and not for the immediate benefit of the particular 
  person holding that office.Â  State v. Oklahoma Corp. Commâ€™n, 971 P.2d 
  868, 871 n 4 (Okla. 1998)(internal citations omitted). The salary pertaining 
  to an office is an incident to the office itself and not to the individual who 
  holds the office. Gaffney v. Mallory, 186 S. C. 337, 341, 195 S. E. 840, 
  844 (1938).Â  Based upon the foregoing, we conclude that sections 4-9-30 and 
  8-21-300 prohibit County from reducing an elected officialâ€™s salary during the 
  terms for which they are elected.
Accordingly, we hold that County did not have the authority to reduce the salary 
  for an Interim Clerk of Court.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Kenneth G. Goode, 
  concur.

 
   [1] Probate Judge Frank Addy served the brief interim 
    between Davisâ€™ retirement and the Governorâ€™s appointment.

 
   [2] Moon won in Novemberâ€™s general election and her 
    elected term of office begins in January 2005. 

 
   [3]  The County contends that the enactment of Â§ 4-9-30(7) 
    in 1987 repealed by implication Â§ 8-21-300 and that Clerks of Court now are 
    covered only by Â§ 4-9-30(7).Â  Repeal by implication is not favored and can 
    be found only where no reasonable construction can be given to two statutes, 
    other than that they are in irreconcilable conflict with each other.Â  Johnston 
    v. City of Myrtle Beach, 283 S.C. 288, 290, 321 S.E.2d 627, 628 (Ct. App. 
    1984).Â  We find these two statutes are not irreconcilable and thus Â§ 4-9-30 
    was not repealed by implication when Â§ 8-21-300 was enacted.

 
   [4] In fact, the Attorney General has issued several 
    opinions in this case concluding that County impermissibly reduced the salary 
    for the Interim Clerk of Court.Â  2003 WL 22682936; 2003 WL 22422699; and 2003 
    WL 22682935 (S.C.A.G.).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
      In the Matter of Former Myrtle Beach Associate Municipal Court
      Judge Phillip W. Hudson,       
      Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25937
Submitted January 4, 2005 - Filed February 
  7, 2005

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Robert E. Bogan, both of Columbia, for The Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 

Thomas C. Brittain, of Myrtle Beach, for respondent.Â Â  
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent 
  and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement 
  for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the 
  agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a 
  public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b)(3), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR. 
  [1] Â  In addition, respondent agrees not to seek or accept any judicial 
  position in South Carolina without permission of the Court.Â  The facts as set 
  forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent was a part-time associate municipal court judge 
  for the City of Myrtle Beach.Â  In addition, respondent was a part-time instructor 
  at Horry-Georgetown Technical College.Â  On March 12, 2004, a Myrtle Beach Police 
  Officer issued two traffic tickets to one of respondentâ€™s students.Â  Traffic 
  court for the charges was scheduled for March 23, 2004.Â  
Respondent admits he engaged in ex parte communication with 
  the student about the tickets.Â  As a result of these communications, respondent 
  marked certain court records falsely to show the disposition of one ticket as 
  â€œdismiss per officerâ€ and the other as â€œdismissed proof.â€Â  As a further result 
  of respondentâ€™s ex parte communications with the student, the student paid respondent 
  $252.00 in two payments on April 1 and April 3, 2004.Â  The student thought the 
  payments were for traffic fines.Â  These payments were made in cash outside the 
  proper procedure for remitting payment of fines.Â  
Respondent did not issue a receipt to the student, did not 
  remit the money to the municipal court, and, instead, commingled the money with 
  his own.Â  Respondent represents it was his intention to remit the money to the 
  municipal court but that he was unable to do so prior to being contacted by 
  Disciplinary Counsel on April 7, 2004.Â  
On at least five prior occasions, respondent accepted money 
  from citizens in his official capacity without properly accounting for it.Â  
  On these occasions, he converted the money to other purposes.Â  
Respondent acknowledges he received a painting from a litigantâ€™s 
  husband on the same day the litigant appeared in court before him; respondent 
  suspended the litigantâ€™s $796.00 fine.Â  Respondent represented he believed the 
  painting was a gift to the municipal court, not to himself.Â  The painting remained 
  in respondentâ€™s office.Â  ODC can neither confirm nor dispute respondentâ€™s representation.Â  

On May 31, 2003, two defendants appeared before respondent 
  for a bond hearing on charges of leaving the scene of an accident involving 
  death.Â  Respondent set a $25,000 surety bond for each defendant.Â  
 Respondent engaged in an ex parte conversation with counsel 
  for one defendant after the hearing.Â  As a result of the ex parte conversation, 
  respondent changed both defendantsâ€™ bonds to personal recognizance without holding 
  another hearing or notifying the victimâ€™s family members.Â  Respondent represents 
  he believed the family members had been notified by the Victimâ€™s Advocate.Â  

Respondentâ€™s term of office expired during the pendency 
  of the disciplinary matters referenced herein.Â  He was not reappointed.Â  
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent has violated the following 
  Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall 
  uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety 
  and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall 
  respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that 
  promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); 
  Canon 2B (judge shall not allow family, social, political or other relationships 
  to influence the judge's judicial conduct or judgment); Canon 3 (judge shall 
  perform the duties of judicial office impartially and diligently); Canon 3B(7) 
  (judge shall not initiate, permit, or consider ex parte 
  communications, or consider other communications made to the judge outside the 
  presence of the parties concerning a pending proceeding); Canon 3B(8) (judge 
  shall dispose of all judicial matters promptly, efficiently, and fairly); Canon 
  4 (judge shall conduct extra-judicial activities as to minimize the risk of 
  conflict with judicial obligations); and Canon 4D(5) (judge shall not accept 
  gift where circumstances might suggest intent to influence judge).Â Â  By violating 
  the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent has also violated Rule 7(a)(1) of the 
  Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR. 
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue 
  a public reprimand. [2] Â  Hereafter, 
  respondent shall neither seek nor accept any judicial office, whether by appointment 
  or election, in this state.Â  See Rule 7(b)(7) and (8), RJDE, Rule 502, 
  SCACR.Â  Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, 
  JJ., concur. 

 
    [1]
    
   
    Respondent no longer holds judicial office.Â  A public reprimand is the most 
    severe sanction the Court can impose when a judge no longer holds judicial 
    office.Â  See In re Oâ€™Kelley, 361 S.C. 30, 603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); 
    In re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996). 

 
    [2]
    
   
    As previously noted, a public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court 
    can impose when a judge no longer holds judicial office.Â  In re Oâ€™Kelley, 
    361 S.C. 30, 603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); In re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 
    S.E.2d 924 (1996).
