THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        City of Charleston, a Municipal Corporation, Robert B. Kizer, and Laura Cabiness, Appellants/Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Thomas J. Masi, Margaret B. Schwochow, John L. Chisolm, Carolyn L. Collins, and June D. Smith, in their capacities as The Charleston County Election Commission, Gertrude D. Brown, Flora P. Condon, Louise M. Hill, Alice K. Mitchell, and Beverly A. Whitney, in their capacities as The Board of Elections and Voter Registration of Charleston County, Respondents,
        And The James Island Public Service District, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25941
Heard January 4, 2005 - Filed February 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Susan Jeanne Herdina, of Charleston; Timothy A. Domin, of Clawson & Staubes, LLC, of Charleston; William B. Regan and Frances I. Cantwell, of Regan and Cantwell, LLC, of Charleston, for appellants/respondents
        Samuel W. Howell, IV, of Howell & Linkous, LLC, of Charleston, for respondents.
        Trent M. Kernodle, David A. Root, Christine C. Varnado, and Robert B. Varnado, of Kernodle, Taylor & Root, of Charleston, for respondent/appellant.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  We dismiss this action as moot and find the trial court did not err by failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees to the James Island Public Service District (District).
FACTS

In June 2002, the Town of James Island (Town) was formed.Â  Thereafter, an action was commenced by the City of Charleston (City), a resident and elector of the City who lives on James Island (Kizer), and a taxpayer and elector of the Town (Cabiness) (jointly referred to as City unless otherwise noted).Â  The complaint sought injunctive relief and declaratory relief as to who, after the incorporation of the Town, was entitled to vote in the District elections and to serve as District commissioners.Â  The complaint alleged that as a function of the incorporation of the Town, which overlapped certain areas in the District, the territorial boundaries of the District were reduced such that Town residents should be prohibited from participating in District elections.
A general election for District commissioners was scheduled for November 5, 2002.Â  The Cityâ€™s motion for a preliminary injunction to stay the November election was denied after a hearing.Â  This matter was heard on the merits and the circuit court issued an order declining to decide the issues raised by the City.Â  The circuit court also denied the Districtâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Both the City and the District appealed.
Subsequent to the filing of this appeal, this Court found the Town of James Island to be a nullity because it had been created by unconstitutional special legislation.Â  Kizer v. Clark, 360 S.C. 86, 600 S.E.2d 529 (2004).
ISSUES


  I.                 Is the Cityâ€™s action moot?
  II.                Did the trial court err by failing to award the District attorneyâ€™s fees?


  DISCUSSION

        I
    

We find the District correctly argues that this case regarding the Town residentsâ€™ entitlement to vote in the District elections and the entitlement to serve as a District commissioner is moot given that the Town is a nullity.Â  Our opinion in Kizer v. Clark, supra, rendered the case nonjusticiable because a judgment, if rendered, would not have any practical legal effect given the Town was deemed nonexistent.Â  See Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 549 S.E.2d 591 (2001), cert. denied, 535 U.S. 926 (2002) (case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon existing controversy); Waters v. South Carolina Land Resources Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 467 S.E.2d 913 (1996) (justiciable controversy is real and substantial controversy appropriate for judicial determination, as opposed to dispute or difference of contingent, hypothetical or abstract character).Â  
The City argues, however, that the Court should decide the issues involved because they are capable of repetition yet evade review and because the issues involve matters of important public interest.Â  We find neither exception is met in this case.
Regarding the exception that a court can take jurisdiction, despite mootness, if the issue raised is capable of repetition but evading review, we find that while the questions involved could arise again, the questions will not â€œusually become mootâ€ before they can be reviewed.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health v. State, 301 S.C. 75, 390 S.E.2d 185 (1990) (although specific case is moot, appeal allowed because raises question that is capable of repetition, but which usually becomes moot before it can be reviewed).Â  Further, the issues involved do not appear to present a â€œrecurring dilemmaâ€ which the Court needs to address to clarify the law.Â  See Evans v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Servs., 303 S.C. 108, 399 S.E.2d 156 (1990) (although development renders case moot, controversy presents a recurring dilemma which the Court will address to clarify the law).
The other exception the City argues is that questions of public interest originally encompassed in an action should be decided for future guidance, however abstract or moot they may have become in the immediate contest.Â  Ashmore v. Greater Greenville Sewer Dist., 211 S.C. 77, 44 S.E.2d 88 (1947); Berry v. Zahler, 220 S.C. 86, 66 S.E.2d 459 (1951) (same).Â  However, pursuant to our opinion in Sloan v. Greenville County, Op. No. 25899 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed November 22, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 45 at 40),Â  we find this case does not fit within the public importance exception to mootness because there is no imperative or manifest urgency in obtaining a decision on whether Town residents can vote in the Districtâ€™s election when the Town does not exist.Â  Further, while ensuring voters are not improperly denied their right to vote in a particular election is important, the fact remains that the pertinent issue does not present a recurring dilemma such that this issue should be addressed to clarify the law.Â  Compare Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 2003) (important public interest exists in stewardship of public funds and strong need exists to provide guidance for future procurement decisions) and Sloan v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 342 S.C. 515, 537 S.E.2d 299 (Ct. App. 2000) (same) with Sasser v. South Carolina Democratic Party, 277 S.C. 67, 282 S.E.2d 602 (1981) (appeal from circuit court order sustaining demurrers to petition to nullify results of primary election for political partyâ€™s nomination to State House of Representatives was rendered moot, where general election had already occurred).
Accordingly, this case is dismissed as moot.
II

Following the circuit courtâ€™s order finding there were no rights to declare in the declaratory judgment action, the District moved for attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (Supp. 2003).Â  Section 15-77-300 provides:

  In any civil action brought by the State, any political subdivision of the State or any party who is contesting state action, unless the prevailing party is the State or any political subdivision of the State, the court may allow the prevailing party to recover reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees to be taxed as court costs against the appropriate agency if:
  
    
      
        (1)
        The court finds that the agency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim against the party; and
      
      
        (2)
        The court finds that there are no special circumstances that would make the award of attorney’s fees unjust.  . . .
      
    
  

The circuit court found the District was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees because the District was not a â€œprevailing partyâ€ and the City had a substantial justification in bringing the action.
There are three prerequisites that must be established prior to the recovery of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs by a party contesting state action.Â  Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 394 S.E.2d 709 (1990).Â  First, the contesting party must be the â€œprevailing party;â€ second, the court must find that the agency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim against the party; and third, the court must find that there are no special circumstances that would make an award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust.Â  Id.
The District is not a prevailing party because its degree of success is nonexistent given that the circuit court did not specifically find for either party and because this case is being dismissed as moot.Â  See Heath v. County of Aiken, supra (court determines prevailing party by evaluating degree of success obtained).Â  Therefore, the circuit court did not err by denying the Districtâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  See Heath v. County of Aiken, supra (award of attorneyâ€™s fees will not be disturbed absent abuse of discretion).Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Regina Spruill,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richland County School District 2, Employer, and EBI Companies, Carrier,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25942
Heard September 23, 2004 - Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John S. Nichols, of Bluestein & Nichols, LLC, and Preston F. McDaniel, 
  of McDaniel & Johnson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
W. Hugh McAngus, of McAngus Goudelock & Courie, LLC, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  This is a workerâ€™s compensation 
  case.Â  Appellant (Employee) contends the single commissioner erred in refusing 
  to allow Employee to withdraw her Form 50 following the hearing.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In December 1999, Employee 
  obtained a report from Dr. Fechter.Â  Employee believed Dr. Fechterâ€™s report 
  found a link between Employeeâ€™s disability and her workplace exposure to dust 
  created by construction work.Â  On January 3, 2000, Employee made Dr. Fechterâ€™s 
  report available to respondents.Â  When respondents sought to depose the doctor, 
  they learned he was out of the country.Â  Respondents requested relief.Â  As a 
  result, the hearing, which had been scheduled for January 13, was moved to January 
  17 by the hearing commissioner, who also ordered that the record would remain 
  open to allow respondents to depose Dr. Fechter.Â  No party objected to these 
  rulings.
Dr. Fechter was deposed 
  on January 28, 2000. Â In this deposition he â€˜clarifiedâ€™ his earlier report, 
  opining that Employeeâ€™s disability was the result of an idiopathic disease and 
  not connected to her earlier exposure to dust and debris at her place of employment.Â  
  In late April 2000, the single commissioner informed the parties of her decision 
  to deny Employeeâ€™s permanent disability claim.Â  Several days later, Employee 
  sought to withdraw her Form 50, relying upon 25A S.C. Regulation 67-609 (Supp. 
  2003).Â  The single commissioner denied this request, and her ruling was affirmed 
  by the full commission and the circuit court.Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUE

Does Regulation 67-609 permit 
  a claimant to withdraw her Form 50 at any time?

ANALYSIS
Employee contends that 
  Regulation 67-609 permits a claimant to withdraw her Form 50 â€œonce as a matter 
  of right with leave to renewâ€ at any point in the proceeding.Â  The commissioner 
  held that a claimant could not withdraw her Form 50 after the hearing had been 
  held and a decision rendered.Â  We agree that Regulation 67-609 applies only 
  where the request is made prior to the hearing.
Regulation 67-609 provides:

67-609.Â  Withdrawing a Request 
  for Hearing.
  
  A.     A claimant may withdraw a Form 50 or Form 52 once 
  as a matter of right with leave to renew.
    
  (1)     A Form 50 or 52 may be withdrawn by writing 
  the Commissionâ€™s Judicial Department, if a hearing notice has not been issued, 
  or, the Commissionerâ€™s office identified on the hearing notice.
  (2)     When a Form 50 or Form 52 is withdrawn, 
  a notice removing the case from the docket will be filed in the Commissionâ€™s 
  record and a copy mailed to the parties in R. 67-210.
    
  B.      The notice is without prejudice to the claimantâ€™s 
  right to proceed with his or her claim.
    
  (1)     If the nature of the claim and the relief 
  requested does not change, write the Judicial Department requesting the Form 
  50 or Form 52 be reset for hearing.
  (2)     If the nature of the claim or relief requested 
  changes, file according to R. 67-207, a new Form 50 or Form 52 with the word 
  â€œAmendedâ€ printed or typed boldly on the top of the form.
    
  C.      Withdrawing a Form 50 or Form 52 the second 
  time without good cause may operate as a voluntary dismissal of the claim when 
  the form is withdrawn by a claimant who has once withdrawn a Form 50 or Form 
  52 based on the same set of facts, and, in the opinion of the Commissioner, 
  the form is withdrawn merely for the purpose of delay.
  D.     Withdrawing a Form 15 request for hearing waives 
  the sixty day hearing requirement.Â  If the jurisdictional commissioner is unable 
  to reschedule the case, the file will be returned to the Judicial Department 
  to be reassigned.
  

The first sentence of Regulation 
  67-609(A), read in isolation, supports Employeeâ€™s contention.Â  We do not, however, 
  determine the meaning of a regulation by reading its component parts in isolation, 
  but rather construe the regulation as a whole.Â  See Byerly v. Connor, 
  307 S.C. 441, 415 S.E.2d 796 (1992). 
The purpose of the regulation 
  is reflected in its title, Withdrawing a Request for a Hearing, and the text 
  reflects this limited application.Â  Regulation 67-609(A)(1) requires the claimant 
  to notify the Judicial Department if the withdrawal is made before the hearing 
  notice has been issued: if made after the notice has been issued, then the withdrawal 
  should be directed to the commissioner assigned to hear the case.Â  Regulation 
  67-609(B) provides that if the refiled claim and relief are unchanged, the claimant 
  should simply request the matter â€œbe reset for hearing.â€Â  If, however, the nature 
  of the claim or relief changes, then the claimant must file an amended Form 
  50 and comply with Regulation 67-207, which outlines the procedures to be followed 
  by a claimant requesting a hearing.Â  Regulation 67-609(B)(2). 
Regulation 67-609 contemplates 
  that the withdrawal request will be made prior to the hearing before the single 
  commissioner and provides the procedures for requesting a new hearing date.Â  
  Nothing in this regulation supports Employeeâ€™s assertion that she is entitled 
  to withdraw her Form 50 at any point in the process.
Further, we traditionally defer 
  to an executive agencyâ€™s construction of its own regulation.Â  Such a construction 
  is â€œaccorded most respectful consideration and will not be overturned absent 
  compelling reasons.â€Â  E.g., Dorman v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health 
  and Enviro. Control, 350 S.C. 159, 565 S.E.2d 119 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Even 
  if Regulation 67-609 were ambiguous, we would defer to the commissionâ€™s interpretation 
  since it reflects a sound policy decision not to permit disgruntled claimants 
  a second â€œbite at the apple.â€
CONCLUSION
Regulation 67-609 did 
  not entitle Employee to withdraw her Form 50 following the single commissionerâ€™s 
  hearing.Â  The circuit court order, upholding the denial of Employeeâ€™s request, 
  is 
AFFIRMED. 
  [1] 
 MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting 
  in a separate opinion.

 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully 
  dissent.Â  In my view, the circuit court erred in affirming the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commissionâ€™s decision forbidding Employee from withdrawing her Form 50.Â  Therefore, 
  I would reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision and remand this case with instructions 
  permitting the Employee to withdraw the form.Â Â  
The majority holds that a Form 50 must be withdrawn 
  before a hearing commences, or a claimant loses the right to withdraw the form.Â  
  I do not agree with this holding because (1) it is not supported by the terms 
  of the controlling regulation and (2) it imposes even stricter requirements 
  than those imposed by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.
The controlling regulation provides that â€œ[a] claimant 
  may withdraw a Form 50 . . . once as a matter of right with leave to 
  renew.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-609(A) (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).Â  
  Given its plain and ordinary meaning, this regulation, in my view, does not 
  require that the Form 50 be withdrawn at any particular time in the proceeding.Â 
See Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 444, 415 S.E.2d 796, 799 (1992) 
  (â€œThe words of a regulation must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without 
  resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the regulationâ€™s 
  operation.â€).Â  Had the appropriate rulemaking agency intended to impose the 
  requirement established by the majority todayâ€”that a claimant must withdraw 
  the form before the hearing commencesâ€”the agency would have done so.Â Â Â  
In addition, the majorityâ€™s holding imposes stricter 
  limitations on the right to withdraw than those imposed by the Commission itself.Â  
  In the case at hand, the Commission ruled that â€œ[o]nce a hearing is convened, 
  concluded, and a determination rendered, the claimant cannot withdraw the Form 
  50.â€Â  This ruling, in my view, provides that a claimant may not withdraw the 
  form after a determination has been rendered, not before the hearing 
  commences, as the majority holds.Â  
In the present case, a decision had yet to be rendered 
  when Employee sought to withdraw the form.Â  On May 8, 2000, Employee requested 
  that the Form 50 be withdrawn.Â  At that time, the Commission had merely written 
  a letter asking the attorneys to draft an order.Â  Attached to the letter were 
  â€œnotesâ€ outlining the Commissionâ€™s findings.Â  The final order incorporating 
  these findings was not signed until September 6, 2000.Â Â Â  
Given these facts, it is my opinion that the letter 
  and its accompanying notes do not constitute an order, and until an order has 
  been issued, and the case removed from the docket, Employee had the right to 
  withdraw the Form 50.Â  

 
   [1]  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s rulings on the remaining 
    issues raised by Employee pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following 
    authority: Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 
    272 (2004).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State,           
        Petitioner/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gerrod Lewis,       
Respondent/Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALSÂ Â  

Appeal From Dorchester County
Luke N. Brown, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25943
Heard November 16, 2004 - Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Assistant 
  Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Robert D. Robbins, 
  of Summerville, for petitioner/respondent.
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for respondent/petitioner.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent/petitioner (Lewis) and his co-defendant, 
  Timothy Washington, were convicted of first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC), 
  two counts of kidnapping, grand larceny of a vehicle, and armed robbery.Â  Lewis 
  was sentenced to concurrent terms of thirty years for CSC, thirty years for 
  each kidnapping charge, five years for grand larceny, and thirty years for armed 
  robbery. [1] Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed 
  in part, reversed in part, and remanded.Â  State v. Lewis, 354 S.C. 222, 
  580 S.E.2d 149 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Judge Anderson dissented.Â  We now affirm in 
  part and reverse in part.
ISSUES

  
    
      
I. Did the Court of Appeals err by affirming the trial courtâ€™s failure to suppress 
  an in-court identification?
II. Did the Court of Appeals err by holding the trial court improperly disallowed 
  Lewisâ€™s attempt to strike a juror who had previously been struck in violation 
  of Batson? [2] 
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
I
Lewis argues the Court of 
  Appeals erred by affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision not to suppress an in-court 
  identification or to require an in camera hearing prior to the in-court 
  identification.
Gill Armstrong and Jane 
  Doe [3]  were driving from Virginia to their home in 
  Florida with their seven-month-old daughter when they stopped at a motel off 
  I-95 in St. George about 11:00 p.m.Â  Armstrong then left to get food.Â  Upon 
  his return, he noticed three black males in the breezeway of the motel and assumed 
  they were guests of the motel.Â  He had a direct view of the men because of the 
  fluorescent lighting in the breezeway.Â  After taking the food into the hotel 
  room, Armstrong then went to the vending machines to get drinks.Â  As he began 
  to place money in the machine, the three men walked up to him and placed a gun 
  to the back of his head.
The men then forced him 
  into the motel room.Â  Before entering the room, the men turned him around and 
  Armstrong saw Washington holding the gun to his head.Â  When they entered the 
  room, the lights were on.Â  Doe was just getting out of the shower and was clad 
  only in a towel.Â  Lewis asked where the money and jewelry was.Â  While Lewis 
  was digging in a duffel bag, Washington instructed Lewis to turn off the lights.Â  
  Before the lights were turned off, Armstrong was able to view his assailants 
  for a few minutes. 
After the men did not find 
  anything, Washington pointed the gun at Armstrongâ€™s daughter who was still asleep 
  and said, â€œIf you try anything, sheâ€™s gone.â€Â  The men became extremely angry 
  when they discovered the couple had only $14.Â  At this point, Armstrong was 
  taken into the bathroom and was placed on his knees, bending over into the bathtub, 
  with the gun pointed at him.Â  At first, Lewis held Armstrong in the bathroom 
  at gunpoint, but then the third man, Shermaine Elmore, 
  [4]  switched with Lewis.
Doe testified that two of 
  the men, allegedly Lewis and Washington, then took turns forcing her to perform 
  oral sex on them.Â  Washington then took Doe into the bathroom, bent her over 
  the toilet, and raped her while forcing Armstrong to watch.Â  Then, the men asked 
  for Armstrongâ€™s car keys.Â  As they left, Washington told Armstrong â€œHappy Fatherâ€™s 
  Day.â€ [5] Â  The men then took the coupleâ€™s car and burned 
  it.
Doe was not able to give 
  a description of the attackers. [6] Â  However, Armstrong told the 
  police that the men were black males and gave general descriptions of their 
  height, facial hair, and clothing. [7] Â  A few days later, Shermaine Elmore informed the police he 
  was the lookout during the crimes.Â  Elmore told the police that Washington and 
  Lewis were the two men who sexually assaulted Doe.Â  Armstrong confirmed at trial 
  that Elmore had no involvement in the sexual assault.
At trial, Armstrong identified 
  Washington and Lewis as the perpetrators.Â  In fact, Armstrong stated he was 
  â€œ100 percent positiveâ€ in his identification of Lewis.Â  Further, Armstrong testified 
  the individuals that committed the crimes were â€œstuck in [his] mind.â€Â  Counsel 
  objected to the in-court identification and requested an in camera hearing 
  to determine the reliability of his identification.Â  The trial judge denied 
  the request, and ruled that Armstrong could identify the defendants in court, 
  even though Armstrong had never previously identified them. [8] 
The Court of Appeals held 
  that, since Armstrong had never previously identified the defendants, no hearing 
  was necessary. [9] Â  The court further held that 
  the reliability of Armstrongâ€™s identification was a question for the jury and 
  that Lewisâ€™ counsel extensively cross-examined Armstrong regarding the identification.Â  
  In his dissent, Judge Anderson concurred in the result but found that the trial 
  judge should have held an in camera hearing to determine the reliability 
  of Armstrongâ€™s identification.
The Court of Appealsâ€™ 
  decision represents the majority view that the Neil v. Biggers 
  [10]  analysis should not be extended to protect criminal defendants against 
  identifications that occur for the first time in court without a pre-trial identification.Â  
  In Neil v. Biggers, the United States Supreme Court found that a court 
  must review the totality of the circumstances to determine whether an identification 
  is reliable.Â  See also State v. Scipio, 283 S.C. 124, 322 S.E.2d 
  15 (1984).Â  The factors to be considered in evaluating the likelihood of misidentification 
  include:Â  (1) the opportunity of the witness to view the accused; (2) the witnessâ€™ 
  degree of attention; (3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™ prior description; (4) 
  the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the confrontation; and 
  (5) the length of time between the crime and the confrontation.Â  Neil v. 
  Biggers, 409 U.S. at 199; State v. Drayton, 293 S.C. 417, 361 S.E.2d 
  329 (1987), cert. denied, 484 U.S. 1079 (1988).
We conclude, as the majority 
  of courts have, that Neil v. Biggers does not apply to in-court identifications 
  and that the remedy for any alleged suggestiveness of an in-court identification 
  is cross-examination and argument.Â  The United States Supreme Court has not 
  extended its exclusionary rule to in-court identification procedures that are 
  suggestive because of the trial setting.Â  See State v. Smith, 
  512 A.2d 189, 193 (Conn. 1986).
The Georgia supreme 
  court has stated, â€œ[b]ecause pretrial identification procedures occur beyond 
  the immediate supervision of the court, the likelihood of misidentification 
  in such cases increases, and courts have required that pretrial identification 
  procedures comport with certain minimum constitutional requirements in order 
  to ensure fairness.â€Â  Ralston v. State, 309 S.E.2d 135, 136 (Ga. 1983).Â  
  See also United States v. Domina, 784 F.2d 1361 (9th 
  Cir. 1986), cert. denied, 479 U.S. 1038 (1987) (concern with in-court 
  identification, where there has been suggestive pretrial identification, is 
  that witness later identifies the person in court, not from his recollection 
  of observations at time of crime, but from suggestive pretrial identification).Â  
  However, as the Ralston court explained, these extra safeguards are not 
  applicable to an in-court identification because the witnessâ€™ testimony is subject 
  to the same rules of evidence, witness credibility, and cross-examination as 
  all testimony in a criminal trial.Â  Ralston v. State, 309 S.E.2d at 136-137.Â  
  See also United States v. Bush, 749 F.2d 1227 (7th 
  Cir. 1984), cert. denied, 470 U.S. 1058 (1985) (deference shown jury 
  in weighing reliability of potentially suggestive out-of-court identification 
  would seem even more appropriate for in-court identifications where jury is 
  present and able to see first-hand the circumstances which may influence a witness); 
  People v. Brazeau, 759 N.Y.S.2d 268 (N.Y. 2003) (where there has not 
  been a pretrial identification and defendant is identified in court for first 
  time, defendant is not deprived of fair trial because defendant is able to explore 
  weaknesses and suggestiveness of identification in front of the jury); State 
  v. Smith, 512 A.2d 189 (Conn. 1986) (defendantâ€™s protection against obvious 
  suggestiveness in courtroom identification confrontation is his right to cross-examination); 
  People v. Rodriguez, 480 N.E.2d 1147, 1151 (Ill. App. 1985) cert. 
  denied, 475 U.S. 1089 (1986) (where witness first identifies defendant at 
  trial, defense counsel may test perceptions, memory, and bias of witness, contemporaneously 
  exposing weaknesses and adding perspective to lessen hazards of undue weight 
  or mistake). 
 Accordingly, we 
  conclude Neil v. Biggers does not apply to a first-time in-court identification 
  because the judge is present and can adequately address relevant problems; the 
  jury is physically present to witness the identification, rather than merely 
  hearing testimony about it; and cross-examination offers defendants an adequate 
  safeguard or remedy against suggestive examinations.Â  Therefore, the Court of 
  Appeals properly concluded the trial court did not err by denying Lewisâ€™ request 
  for an in camera hearing prior to the in-court identification by Armstrong. 
  [11] Â  In any event, Armstrongâ€™s in-court identification was strong, detailed, 
  and clear, and would have survived an in camera hearing.
II
The State argues the Court of Appeals erred by holding the trial judge improperly 
  disallowed Lewisâ€™ attempt to strike a juror who had previously been struck for 
  discriminatory reasons in violation of Batson. 
  [12] 
During jury selection, Lewis exercised peremptory strikes on nine white jurors.Â  
  His co-defendant, Washington, also separately struck nine white jurors, including 
  juror 304, a white female.Â  At the end of jury selection, the State requested 
  a Batson hearing.Â  Each defendant separately presented reasons for his 
  respective strikes.Â  Lewis stated he did not want housewives to be jurors and 
  that is why he struck two white females.Â  Washington explained he struck juror 
  304 because she was a housewife.Â  In argument, the State pointed out that neither 
  Washington nor Lewis had struck Juror 166, who was also a housewife.Â  The trial 
  court found several jurors, including juror 304, had been struck for reasons 
  not race-neutral or gender-neutral.Â  The parties then began selecting a second 
  jury.
Juror 304 was presented again.Â  Washington accepted the juror, but 
  Lewis attempted to strike her.Â  At that point, the trial court asked the attorneys 
  to approach the bench and told Lewisâ€™ attorney he could not strike the juror 
  because the court had already held that the reason for the previous strike was 
  pretextual.Â  Lewis therefore accepted the juror.Â  After finishing the second 
  jury selection process, Lewis moved to quash the jury and re-select another 
  jury because he was not allowed to exercise a peremptory strike.Â  Lewisâ€™ counsel 
  argued he should be allowed to strike juror 304 because he had an independent 
  reason to strike her, i.e. due to her demeanor.Â  The trial court denied 
  the motion and stated counsel was â€œstuck with [the reason] given the first time.â€
The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court on the grounds that 
  Lewis had not previously attempted to strike the juror, only Washington had, 
  and because Lewis gave a race-neutral reason for striking the juror that was 
  different from Washingtonâ€™s reason.
We find the Court of Appeals erred by reversing the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision not to allow Lewis to strike a juror who had previously been stricken 
  in violation of Batson.Â  See State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 
  512 S.E.2d 500 (1999) (trial courtâ€™s findings of purposeful discrimination rest 
  largely on courtâ€™s evaluation of demeanor and credibility, and reviewing court 
  should give the findings great deference on appeal).
As we stated in State v. Franklin, 318 S.C. 47, 456 S.E.2d 
  357, cert. denied, 516 U.S. 856 (1995), to hold that a trial court may 
  not seat a juror who was previously improperly excluded by defense counsel due 
  to a Batson violation would reward a party for his own improper conduct. [13] Â  Lewis offered a reason for striking juror 
  304, i.e., due to her demeanor, [14]  that was different from the 
  reason his co-defendant struck juror 304, i.e. she was a housewife.Â  
  However, the previous discriminatory explanation that the juror was stricken 
  because she was a housewife tainted the selection process.Â  This is true regardless 
  of the other explanations for the strike.Â  See Payton v. Kearse, 
  329 S.C. 51, 495 S.E.2d 205 (1998) (discriminatory explanation vitiates entire 
  selection process regardless of genuineness of other explanations for the strike).Â  
  â€œTo excuse such obvious prejudice because the challenged party can also articulate 
  nondiscriminatory reasons for the peremptory strike would erode what little 
  protection Batson provides against discrimination in jury selection.â€Â  
  Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. at 60, 495 S.E.2d at 210.Â  See also 
  Coleman v. Hogan, 486 S.E.2d 548 (Va. 1997) (allowing a constitutionally 
  proper reason to override a constitutionally infirm reason if the acceptable 
  reason is given later would erode the constitutional protections enunciated 
  in Batson and its progeny).
To allow a striking party to challenge the reseated juror a second 
  time would require the trial court to ignore its prior determination and the 
  prior explanations and conduct each successive evaluation of a newly proffered 
  rationale as if on a blank slate.Â  Coleman v. Hogan, supra.Â  Such 
  a process improperly restricts the ability of the trial court to make the required 
  evaluation.Â  Id.
We conclude that once a juror has been unconstitutionally stricken, 
  the jury selection process relative to that juror is tainted.Â  If the trial 
  court chooses to reseat the improperly stricken juror, the striking party may 
  not use a peremptory strike to remove that juror from the panel a second time.
CONCLUSION
We find the Court of Appeals properly affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision not 
  to suppress an in-court identification.Â  However, we find the Court of Appeals 
  erred by finding the trial court had erred by not allowing Lewis to strike a 
  juror who had previously been struck in violation of Batson.Â  Therefore, 
  the decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice A. Victor 
  Rawl, concur.

 
   [1] Washington 
    received a sentence of life imprisonment without parole for the two kidnapping 
    charges, the first-degree CSC charge, and the armed robbery charge.Â  He also 
    received five yearsâ€™ imprisonment for each of the following charges:Â  unlawful 
    possession of a pistol, possession of a weapon during a certain crime, and 
    grand larceny.Â  All of the sentences were to be served consecutively.

 
   [2] Batson 
    v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986). 

 
   [3] To 
    protect the female victimâ€™s identity, she will be referred to as Jane Doe.

 
   [4] Elmore 
    pled guilty to armed robbery and grand larceny on the first day of trial.Â  
    Armstrong testified that Elmore was not involved in the assault on Doe.

 
   [5] The 
    crimes occurred on Fatherâ€™s Day in 1999.

 
   [6] Further, 
    Doe could not identify who had attacked her after viewing a photo line-up 
    that contained all three of the alleged assailants.

 
   [7] The 
    descriptions were as follows:Â  (1) black male wearing a black hat and black 
    coat, mustache, goatee, approximately 6 feet, 2 inches tall, and weighing 
    approximately 175 pounds; identified as Washington at trial; (2) tall black 
    male with slim build wearing baggy jeans and a t-shirt with green lettering, 
    approximately 6 feet, 4 inches tall, and weighing approximately 175 pounds; 
    identified as Elmore at trial; and (3) black male of medium height, medium 
    build, no clothing description, approximately 6 feet tall, and weighing approximately 
    175 pounds; identified as Lewis at trial.

 
   [8] Armstrong 
    was unable to return to South Carolina from Florida before the trial due to 
    medical reasons.

 
   [9] The 
    Court of Appeals found that the protection afforded a defendant when there 
    has been an out-of-court identification does not apply to the situation where 
    there has been only an in-court identification.Â  If there had been a pre-trial 
    identification, a hearing is mandated on the admissibility of that identification.Â  
    See Rule 104(c), SCRE (hearings on admissibility of pretrial identifications 
    of an accused shall in all cases be conducted out of the juryâ€™s hearing); 
    State v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 101, 561 S.E.2d 618 (2002) (in camera 
    hearing required by Rule 104(c) allows defendant to question witness more 
    stringently regarding possible misidentification or bias outside juryâ€™s presence; 
    per se rule requiring court to hold in camera hearing when State 
    offers identification testimony and defendant challenges in-court identification 
    as being tainted by previous illegal identification.).

 
   [10] Neil 
    v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972).

 
   [11] Regarding 
    Lewisâ€™ argument that the trial court should have conducted a photographic 
    lineup prior to Armstrong being allowed to give an in-court identification, 
    we find there is no constitutional entitlement to an in-court line-up or other 
    particular method of lessening the suggestiveness of an in-court identification.Â  
    See United States v. Domina, 784 F.2d 1361, 1369 (9th 
    Cir. 1986), cert. denied, 479 U.S. 1038 (1987); State v. Smith, 
    512 A.2d 189 (Conn. 1986).

 
   [12] Batson 
    v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986). 

 
   [13] We 
    disagree with the Court of Appealsâ€™ conclusion that Lewis should have been 
    allowed to strike Juror 304 because co-defendant Washington had previously 
    improperly struck the juror instead of Lewis.Â  We defer to the trial courtâ€™s 
    conclusion that the defendants were acting in concert when using their peremptory 
    strikes.Â  See State v. Ford, supra (reviewing court should 
    give trial courtâ€™s findings regarding purposeful discrimination great deference 
    on appeal).

 
   [14] The demeanor of a juror is 
    normally a legitimate reason for striking a juror.Â  See State v. 
    Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 545 S.E.2d 805, cert. denied, 534 U.S. 977 
    (2001) (demeanor of venire member when responding to questions about ability 
    to impose death penalty provided valid racially neutral explanation for Stateâ€™s 
    peremptory strike); State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 512 S.E.2d 99, cert. 
    denied, 527 U.S. 1042 (1999) (counsel may strike venire persons based 
    on their demeanor and disposition).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
S.C. Coastal Conservation League, Coastal Conservation Association - 
        South Carolina, Beth Keyserling-Kramer, Frank DeMarco, Karen DeMarco,

Gautreaux,

South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office 
        of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management, and LandTech of Charleston,
L.L.C.,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25944
Heard October 20, 2004 - Filed February 
  22, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Leslie West Stidham, of Charleston, for Appellant South Carolina Department 
  of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management; 
  Ellison D. Smith, IV, of Smith, Bundy, Bybee & Barnett, of Mt. Pleasant, 
  and James B. Richardson, of Richardson & Birdsong, of Columbia, for Appellant 
  LandTech of Charleston, L.L.C.
G. Trenholm Walker and Amanda Rajsich Maybank, both of Pratt-Thomas, Epting 
  & Walker, PA, of Charleston, for Respondents.
Neil C. Robinson, Jr. and Paul A. Dominick, both of Nexsen Pruet Adams Kleemeier, 
  LLC, of Charleston, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Tourism Council, Inc. 
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES: This case involves a permit to build a concrete bridge 
  for vehicular traffic over â€œcritical areaâ€ as defined in South Carolina Code 
  section 48-39-10(J). [1] Â  The 
  South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean 
  and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM) granted the permit.Â  After a contested 
  hearing, the Administrative Law Judge Division (ALJD) upheld the grant.Â  On 
  appeal the Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel of OCRM (the Panel) affirmed.Â  
  The circuit court reversed and vacated the permit.Â  We certified the case for 
  review under Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision and 
  reinstate the permit.
FACTS
LandTech of Charleston, L.L.C. (LandTech) applied to OCRM for a permit to build 
  a bridge across the marshes of the Wando River to Park Island in the Town of 
  Mt. Pleasant.Â  OCRM staff deemed Park Island a small island and therefore considered 
  the permit application governed by the access-to-small-islands regulation, Regulation 
  30-12(N) (Small Islands Regulation). [2] Â Â Â  LandTech claimed that Park 
  Island was not a small island and that the application was governed by the transportation-projects 
  regulation, Regulation 30-12(F) (Transportation Regulation). [3] Â  OCRM disagreed and processed the permit application under 
  the Small Islands Regulation, the criteria of which are more stringent than 
  those of the Transportation Regulation.Â  OCRM granted the permit.Â  
Respondents objected and requested a contested hearing before the ALJD.Â  At 
  the hearing, LandTech raised its argument that Park Island was not a small island 
  and that the Transportation Regulation, not the Small Islands Regulation, governed.Â  
  Respondents countered that Park Island was a small island and that the criteria 
  for the grant of a permit for bridge access had not been met.Â  OCRM staff agreed 
  with Respondents that Park Island was a small island but argued that the Small 
  Islands Regulation was satisfied.Â  
The Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) observed that â€œsmall islandâ€ is not defined 
  in the regulations and decided â€œthere needs to be some standard to guide the 
  OCRM in its application of its regulation dealing with bridges to islands.â€Â  
  The ALJ compared Park Island only to other islands within the Wando River basin; 
  islands in other coastal areas were not considered.Â  Because Park Island was 
  larger than eighty percent of the Wando River basinâ€™s islands, the ALJ found 
  that Park Island was not a small island.Â  He therefore adopted LandTechâ€™s position 
  that the application was governed by the Transportation Regulation, not the 
  Small Islands Regulation.Â  He held that the Transportation Regulation was satisfied 
  and upheld the permit. 
Nevertheless, because OCRM staff had granted the permit under the Small Islands 
  Regulation, the ALJ addressed whether the permit complied with that regulation 
  assuming Park Island were small.Â  He found that each factor in the regulation 
  that OCRM must consider weighed in favor of granting the permit.Â  He stated 
  that even if the Small Islands Regulation were the governing regulation, its 
  criteria had been satisfied.Â  
Respondents appealed to the Panel, which affirmed without analysis.Â  
Respondents then appealed to the circuit court, which reversed.Â  With respect 
  to the issue whether the Transportation Regulation or Small Islands Regulation 
  governed, the court held that the ALJ erred by using a test not promulgated 
  by regulation.Â  The court deferred to OCRM staff and found that Park Island 
  was in fact a small island and that the permit application was therefore governed 
  by the Small Islands Regulation.Â  The court held that the permitâ€™s issuance 
  did not comply with that regulationâ€™s criteria.Â  
In addition, the circuit court held that there was not substantial evidence 
  to support the finding that the permitâ€™s issuance complied with the regulation 
  requiring OCRM to consider the direct and cumulative effects of a project, Regulation 
  30-11 (Effects Regulation). [4] Â  
  The court vacated the grant of the permit.
LandTech appeals, arguing that the Transportation Regulation is the 
  governing project-specific regulation and that its criteria are satisfied.Â  
  OCRM also appeals, arguing that the Small Islands Regulation governs and that 
  its criteria are satisfied.Â  Both argue that the grant of the permit complies 
  with the Effects Regulation.
ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Whether the Transportation Regulation or the Small Islands Regulation 
  is the governing project-specific regulation.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Whether the grant of the permit complies with the governing project-specific 
  regulation.
III.Â Â Â Â  Whether the grant of the permit complies with the Effects Regulation.

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The ALJ presided as the finder of fact at the contested hearing.Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B) (Supp. 2003).Â  The Panelâ€™s review of the ALJâ€™s decision was 
  governed by South Carolina Code section 1-23-610(D). [5] Â  The circuit courtâ€™s appellate review of the Panelâ€™s decision 
  was governed by section 1-23-380(A)(6), 
  [6]  which also governs this Courtâ€™s review of the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  
  Brown v. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 512, 560 S.E.2d 
  410, 413 (2002).
ANALYSIS
South Carolina Code section 48-39-30 
  [7]  sets forth state policy with respect to development of critical area.Â  
  Section 48-39-150 [8]  lists general 
  considerations for OCRM to consider when deciding whether to grant a permit.Â  
  The Effects Regulation repeats these policies and considerations and further 
  requires OCRM to consider the cumulative effects of a project in critical area.Â  
  Regulation 30-12 [9]  sets forth project-specific criteria for proposed 
  construction in critical area, including transportation projects and projects 
  for access to small islands.
I.Â  The Governing Project-Specific RegulationÂ  
The circuit court held that the Small Islands Regulation, not the Transportation 
  Regulation, was the governing project-specific regulation.Â  We disagree.
â€œAs a creature of statute,â€ OCRM has â€œonly those powers expressly conferred 
  or necessarily implied for it to effectively fulfill the duties with which it 
  is charged.â€Â  Captainâ€™s Quarters Motor Inn, Inc. v. S.C. Coastal Council, 
  306 S.C. 488, 490, 413 S.E.2d 13, 14 (1991).Â  OCRM has the duty to approve or 
  deny permit applications.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-50(G) (Supp. 2003).Â  To fulfill 
  this duty, OCRM must promulgate rules and regulations.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-130(B) 
  (Supp. 2003).
Whether an island is small is the threshold issue in determining whether the 
  Transportation Regulation or the Small Islands Regulation is the governing project-specific 
  regulation.Â  No statute or regulation defines â€œsmall island.â€Â  The circuit court 
  held that the ALJ and Panelâ€™s test for determining whether an island is small 
  - comparing Park Island only to other islands within the same watershed - was 
  invalid because it was not promulgated by regulation.Â  We agree. 
The circuit court also held that Park Island was a small island, using no test 
  but rather deferring to OCRM staff.Â  OCRM and Respondents assert that â€œsmallâ€ 
  is a term of common understanding, so no particular test is necessary.Â  We disagree.
â€œSmallâ€ is a term of subjective relativity, and the regulations provide no 
  benchmark for comparative size.Â  Smallness arguably could be determined per 
  watershed, with respect to all of South Carolinaâ€™s islands, or on an absolute 
  scale.Â  The problem is that there is nothing to interpret or apply. 
  [10] Â  Allowing OCRM to exercise unrestrained discretion is inconsistent 
  with the statute requiring the agency to evaluate permit applications pursuant 
  to regulation. [11] Â  See 
  Captainâ€™s Quarters Motor Inn, Inc., 306 S.C. at 490-91, 413 S.E.2d at 
  14 (invalidating a test used by OCRMâ€™s predecessor in evaluating permit applications 
  because it was not promulgated by regulation); see also 
  Edisto Aquaculture Corp. v. S.C. Wildlife and Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 
  311 S.C. 37, 40, 426 S.E.2d 753, 755 (1993) (distinguishing mandatory agency 
  enabling statutes from permissive ones).Â Â  
That there is no promulgated test means that the Small Islands Regulation fails 
  for vagueness. [12] Â  Any test 
  to determine whether an island is small is invalid as not promulgated by regulation.Â  
  Â Â 
In light of the Small Islands Regulationâ€™s invalidity, the circuit court should 
  have deferred to the Panelâ€™s decision that the permit was governed by the Transportation 
  Regulation.Â  Courts defer to the relevant administrative agencyâ€™s decisions 
  with respect to its own regulations unless there is a compelling reason to differ.Â  
  Brown, 348 S.C. at 515, 560 S.E.2d at 414; Byerly Hosp. v. Health 
  and Human Serv. Fin. Commâ€™n, 319 S.C. 225, 229, 460 S.E.2d 383, 386 (1995).Â  
  The Panel, not OCRM staff, is entitled to deference from the courts.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(A) (Supp. 2003); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-40(A) (Supp. 
  2003); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-150(D) (Supp. 2003); see also Dorman 
  v. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 159, 167, 565 S.E.2d 119, 
  123-24 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
There was no compelling reason to overrule the Panelâ€™s decision that the Transportation 
  Regulation governed.Â  Despite its adoption of the invalid ALJ test to determine 
  whether an island is small, [13] 
   the Panelâ€™s conclusion that the Transportation Regulation controlled was 
  correct.Â  As OCRM Director of Permitting and Certification Richard Chinnis testified, 
  the Transportation Regulation is the default bridge regulation.Â  OCRM staff 
  would have applied it had the staff recognized that the Small Islands Regulation 
  was invalid.
Consequently, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision and hold that the Transportation 
  Regulation was the governing project-specific regulation.Â  
II.Â  Compliance With The Transportation 
  Regulation
After holding that the Transportation Regulation was the governing project-specific 
  regulation, the ALJ held that the regulationâ€™s criteria were met.Â  As already 
  noted, the Panel affirmed without analysis.Â  
The criteria of the Small Islands Regulation are much more stringent than those 
  of the Transportation Regulation.Â  In fact, Respondents have not disputed the 
  meeting of the Transportation Regulationâ€™s criteria. Â Rather, as already discussed, 
  Respondents have argued only that the Small Islands Regulation controls and 
  that its more stringent criteria are not met.Â  Because of our resolution of 
  the first issue, however, we address only the unchallenged ruling that the permitâ€™s 
  issuance complied with the criteria of the Transportation Regulation.Â Â  
A ruling not challenged on appeal is the law of the case, regardless of the 
  correctness of the ruling.Â  S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.E.C.U.R.E. 
  Underwriters Risk Retention Group, 353 S.C. 249, 251, 578 S.E.2d 8, 9 n.1 
  (2003).Â  The law of this case is that the grant of the permit complied with 
  the Transportation Regulation.Â Â  
Moreover, notwithstanding the law of the case, there is substantial evidence 
  to support the finding that the grant of the permit complied with the Transportation 
  Regulation.Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify an administrative decision 
  if the findings of fact are not supported by substantial evidence.Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, 
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the 
  conclusion that the administrative agency reached.â€Â  Southeast Res. Recovery, 
  Inc. v. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 358 S.C. 402, 407, 595 S.E.2d 
  468, 470 (2004) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 
  S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981)).Â  â€œ[T]he possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions 
  from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agency's finding from being 
  supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. Pub. Serv. 
  Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984).
There is conflicting evidence in the record regarding the permit issuanceâ€™s 
  compliance with the Transportation Regulation.Â  The evidence that the issuance 
  did comply constitutes substantial evidence.Â  
III.Â  Compliance With The Effects 
  Regulation
Regulation 30-11(B) requires OCRM to consider the direct effects 
  of a project in critical area.Â  Regulation 30-11(C)(1) requires OCRM to be guided 
  by â€œ[t]he extent to which long-range, cumulative effects of the project may 
  result within the context of other possible development and the general character 
  of the area.â€ [14] 
The circuit court held that there was not substantial evidence to support the 
  finding that the grant of the permit complied with the Effects Regulation.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
The record contains conflicting evidence concerning the direct and 
  cumulative effects of building the bridge to Park Island.Â  The evidence that 
  the effects will be minimal constitutes substantial evidence supporting the 
  finding that the permit complies with the Effects Regulation.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s 
  view of the weight of the evidence did not justify vacating the grant of the 
  permit.Â  
CONCLUSION
South Carolina Regulation 30-12(F), the Transportation Regulation, 
  is the project-specific regulation governing this permitâ€™s issuance, and the 
  law of the case is that the issuance complies with the Transportation Regulation.Â  
  Further, there is substantial evidence that the issuance also complies with 
  Regulation 30-11, the Effects Regulation.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision vacating 
  the grant of the permit is therefore
 REVERSED.
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, 
  C.J., concurring in a separate opinion.
 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I agree with the result reached by the 
  majority.Â  In my view, however, OCRM properly granted the permit under the Small 
  Islands Regulation.Â  As the ALJ explained, in a decision affirmed by the Panel, 
  OCRM determines which regulation governs the issuance of a permit on a â€œcase-by-case 
  basis.â€Â  Moreover, the ALJ found that â€œOCRM gave appropriate consideration to 
  the 11 specific requirements under [the Small Islands Regulation] in issuing 
  the bridge permit . . . and the permit satisfies all 11 requirements.â€Â  Accordingly, 
  I agree with the majority that the circuit court decision vacating the grant 
  of the permit should be reversed.

    that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  
    The court may affirm the decision of the agency or remand the case for further 
    proceedings.Â  The court may reverse or modify the decision if substantial 
    rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, 
    inferences, conclusions or decisions are: 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory 
    provisions;
            (b) in excess of the statutory authority

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Alexander Santee Johnson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  25945
Heard November 16, 2005 - Filed February 22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of 
  SC Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald 
  J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  
  A jury convicted Alexander Santee Johnson (Petitioner) of murder.Â  At trial, 
  the judge allowed evidence of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions to be admitted.Â  
  The court of appeals affirmed, holding that, although the trial judge erred 
  in admitting evidence of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions, the error was harmless.Â  
  State v. Johnson, Op. No. 2003-UP-188 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 12, 2003).Â  
  This Court granted certiorari to review the decision of the court of appeals.Â  
  We affirm.
Factual / Procedural Background
Petitioner was convicted 
  of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  On direct appeal, this Court 
  reversed the conviction and remanded the case for a new trial.Â  State v. 
  Johnson, 333 S.C. 62, 508 S.E.2d 29 (1998).
Petitioner was retried 
  for murder in 2000.Â  At trial, Petitioner sought to have his 1986 convictions 
  for second-degree burglary and grand larceny excluded from evidence on the basis 
  that the convictions were more than ten years old.Â  The trial judge ruled that 
  the prior convictions were admissible because they were within ten years of 
  the alleged offense and they were crimes of moral turpitude.
On direct examination, Petitioner acknowledged 
  the prior convictions and stated that he spent thirty days in a juvenile facility 
  when he was twelve or thirteen years old. 
  [1] Â  Petitioner was not questioned about his prior convictions on cross 
  examination.
After closing argument, but before the 
  judge charged the jury, the judge clarified his ruling on the admissibility 
  of the prior convictions.Â  The judge reasoned that the probative value of the 
  prior convictions outweighed their prejudicial effect.
The jury convicted Petitioner of murder, 
  and he appealed.Â  The court of appeals affirmed the decision of the trial court, 
  holding that the admission of the prior convictions was harmless.Â  State 
  v. Johnson, Op. No. 2003-UP-188 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 12, 2003).Â  This 
  Court granted certiorari, and Petitioner now raises the following issues for 
  review:

  
    
       
  Did the trial court apply the proper legal standard in calculating the ten-year 
  time limit under Rule 609(b), SCRE?
      
    
      Did the trial court err by using the moral turpitude standard to determine the 
  admissibility of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions?
      
    
      Did the trial court err in failing to conduct the proper balancing test as set 
  forth by State v. Colf?
      
    
      Did the admission of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions constitute prejudicial error?
  

Law / Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 609(b), 
  SCRE
Petitioner argues that the trial 
  judge erred in admitting Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions because the trial judge 
  did not apply the proper legal standard in calculating the ten-year time limit 
  under Rule 609(b), SCRE.Â  We agree.
Evidence of a prior conviction is admissible 
  to impeach a witness unless a period of more than ten years has elapsed since 
  the date (1) of the conviction or (2) of the release of the witness from confinement 
  for that conviction, whichever date is later.Â  Rule 609(b), SCRE.Â  The evidence 
  is admissible, however, if the trial judge determines that the probative value 
  of the conviction substantially outweighs its prejudicial effect.Â  Id.
 In 1986, Petitioner was sentenced to thirty days 
  as a juvenile for grand larceny and burglary.Â  The record does not reflect which 
  date is later, the date of the conviction or the release from confinement.Â  
  What is certain is that the time of release from confinement and the date of 
  the conviction are both pre-1990.Â  Because Petitionerâ€™s trial was in 2000, the 
  1986 conviction was improperly admitted.Â  Therefore, we hold that the trial 
  court erred in calculating the ten-year time period under Rule 609(b), SCRE.
  II.              
Moral Turpitude Standard 
   
Petitioner 
  argues that the trial judge erred by using the moral turpitude standard to determine 
  that Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions were admissible.Â  We agree, but the issue 
  is not preserved for review.
Under 
  prior common law, moral turpitude was described as â€œan act of baseness, vileness, 
  or depravity in the social duties which a man owes to his fellow man or to society 
  in general, contrary to the accepted and customary rule or right and duty between 
  man and man.â€Â  State v. Harvey, 275 S.C. 225, 227, 268 S.E.2d 587, 588 
  (1980).Â  But the common law rule was replaced when South Carolina adopted Rule 
  609(a), SCRE.Â  Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 432, 527 S.E.2d 98, 100 
  (2000).
Today, 
  the South Carolina Rules of Evidence provide that if the witness has been convicted 
  of a crime that is punishable by death or imprisonment of more than one year, 
  and the probative value of the conviction outweighs its prejudicial effect, 
  the conviction is admissible to attack the witnessâ€™s credibility.Â  Rule 609(a)(1), 
  SCRE.Â  In addition, if the crime involved dishonesty or a false statement the 
  conviction is admissible to attack the witnessâ€™s credibility.Â  Rule 609(a)(2),
SCRE.
 In 
  the present case, Petitioner had prior convictions of burglary and grand larceny.Â  
  To determine whether Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions were admissible, the judge 
  applied the common law moral turpitude test.Â  Because the prior convictions 
  were crimes of moral turpitude, the judge ruled that Petitionerâ€™s convictions 
  were admissible.Â  
Since the adoption of Rule 609, the moral turpitude standard is no longer 
  the proper test for determining the admission of remote prior convictions.Â  
  Therefore, the trial court erred in using the moral turpitude standard to determine 
  the admissibility of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions.
Although 
  we hold that the trial judge erred in applying the moral turpitude standard, 
  we find that Petitioner did not preserve the issue for appellate review.Â  To 
  preserve an issue for review there must be a contemporaneous objection that 
  is ruled upon by the trial court.Â  State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 
  476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996).Â  The objection should be addressed to the trial 
  court in a sufficiently specific manner that brings attention to the exact error.Â  
  State v. Priouleau, 345 S.C. 404, 411, 548 S.E.2d 213, 216 (2001).Â  If 
  a party fails to properly object, the party is procedurally barred from raising 
  the issue on appeal.Â  State v. Pauling, 322 S.C. 95, 99, 470 S.E.2d 106, 
  109Â  (1996).
In 
  the present case, trial counsel did not specifically object to the application 
  of the moral turpitude standard.Â  Instead, trial counsel objected to the admissibility 
  of Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions on the basis that the convictions were too 
  remote.Â  When objecting, counsel stated that â€œitâ€™s now 14 years later.â€Â  Because 
  the objection was clearly based on remoteness and not the use of the moral turpitude 
  standard, we hold that the issue regarding the use of the moral turpitude standard 
  is not preserved for appellate review.
  III.          
Colf 
  Balancing Test  
Petitioner argues that the trial court erred by 
  failing to conduct the proper balancing test in determining whether Petitionerâ€™s 
  prior convictions were admissible.Â  We agree.
This Court has held that a trial judge must conduct 
  a balancing test to determine whether remote convictions are admissible under 
  Rule 609(b).Â  State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 626, 525 S.E.2d 246, 248 (2000).Â  
  Rule 609(b) creates a presumption that remote convictions are inadmissible and 
  places the burden on the State to overcome this presumption.Â  Id. at 
  626-627, 525 S.E.2d at 248.Â Â  When considering whether to admit prior convictions, 
  a trial judge should consider the following factors:

  (1) Â Â Â  The impeachment value of the prior crime;
(2)Â Â Â Â  The point in time of the conviction and 
  the witnessâ€™s subsequent history;
(3)Â Â Â Â  The similarity of the past crime and the 
  charged crime;
(4)Â Â Â Â  The importance of the defendantâ€™s testimony; 
  and
(5) Â Â Â  The centrality of the credibility issue.

Id. at 627, 525 S.E.2d at 248.Â  After the 
  trial court conducts the balancing test, the judge must make a determination 
  and articulate, on the record, the specific reasons for his ruling.Â  Id.
In the present case, the judge explained that the prior 
  convictions were admissible because the probative value outweighed the prejudicial 
  effect.Â  However, the trial judge did not articulate why the probative value 
  outweighed the prejudicial effect.Â  We hold that a trial judge must conduct 
  the Colf balancing test when considering the admission of remote prior 
  convictions with reference to the factors enumerated in that opinion.Â  Therefore, 
  in the present case, the trial court erred by not conducting the proper balancing 
  test. 
  IV.           Harmless 
  Error
Petitioner argues that the admission of the prior convictions constituted prejudicial 
  error.Â  We disagree.
To constitute error, a ruling to admit or exclude evidence must affect a substantial 
  right.Â  Rule 103(a), SCRE.Â  An error is harmless if the defendantâ€™s guilt has 
  been conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other result could 
  have been reached.Â  Prioleau, 345 S.C. at 407-408, 548 S.E.2d at 214-215.Â  
  The circumstances of each individual case are to be considered.Â  State v. 
  Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1986).Â  In addition, the 
  error is harmless if the error could not have reasonably affected the outcome 
  of the trial.Â  Id.
In the present case, defense counsel strategically introduced Petitionerâ€™s prior 
  convictions on direct examination to lessen the impact they might have on Petitionerâ€™s 
  credibility.Â  Furthermore, the prosecution placed no other emphasis on these 
  prior convictions.Â  Therefore, we find that the impact was minimal because other 
  evidence introduced by the prosecution likely damaged Petitionerâ€™s credibility.Â  

For example, there was testimony that upon arrest, Petitioner gave the 
  police a false name.Â  In addition, there was testimony that the fight that led 
  to the death of the victim was over a stolen car.Â  We find that this testimony 
  was more damaging to Petitionerâ€™s credibility than the introduction of the prior 
  convictions.Â  Therefore, the introduction of the prior convictions was not prejudicial 
  to Petitionerâ€™s case.
Because there was overwhelming evidence of Petitionerâ€™s guilt, we do not believe 
  the admission of the Petitionerâ€™s prior convictions could have reasonably affected 
  the outcome of the trial, and therefore the error was harmless. 
Conclusion
For the foregoing 
  reasons, the decision of the court of appeals is AFFIRMED.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., and
Acting Justice A. Victor Rawl, concur.

 
   
    [1]  After the judge ruled against the motion to exclude the prior convictions, 
    Petitioner decided to present evidence of the convictions on direct examination 
    to lessen the impact that they might have on the jury.
